B19: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. The opening is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886.
D83: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4, giving White an imposing central pawn duo. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school, which was coming to the fore in the 1920s, held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchangevariation with White, often involving an early Rb1 to remove the rook from the sensitive a1–h8 diagonal. The Grünfeld Gambit is a variation of the Exchange Variation. White can accept the gambit by playing 6.cxd5 Nxd5 7.Nxd5 Qxd5 8.Bxc7, or decline it with 6.Qb3 or 6.Rc1, to which Black responds with 6...c5. Systems in which White delays the development Nc3 are known as the Neo-Grünfield Defence (ECO code D70–D79) Typical move orders are 1.d4 Nf6 2.g3 g6 3.c4 d5 or, more commonly, 1. d4 nf6. In statistical databases this variation shows only a slightly higher percentage of White wins and draws. B21: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. It is considered to be the best of the irregular defences to 1...P-K4 and 1...e5. The earliest recorded notes on the Sicillian Defence date back to the late 16th century by the Italian chess players Giulio Polerio and Gioachino Greco. Some leading players, such as Emanuel Lasker and Frank Tartakower, still play the Sicilian. Black usually plays 6...e6 (ECO B88 transposed) to limit the range of White's bishop, but White can eventually put pressure on the e6-pawn. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. Top players who have used this variation include Magnus Carlsen. The Kasparov Gambit 8...d5 was played twice in the World Chess Championship 1985, but virtually disappeared from master praxis after the game Karpov–Van der Wiel, Brussels (SWIFT) 1986. Black's move 2...e6 gives priority to developing the dark-squared bishop. Black has three main moves: 4...Nc6 (the Taimanov Variation), 4...a6 ( the Kan Variation) and 4 ...Nf6. White has the option of 6.c4, which solidifies control of d5 and clamps down on ...b5. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings classifies the Sicilian Defence under the codes B20 through B99, giving it more codes than any other opening.

D41: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5; 1. d4 d52 c4 e4 2. c4 d5 3. c5 e4 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 6...Bf3 or 6...Q2 is also popular. The opening became a topical line after its adoption by Mikhail Botvinnik in 1963. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4; or 4. e3 which may lead to the Stonewall Dutch after ...f5 or transpose to the Semi-Slav. 3...Bb4 (the Accelerated Ragozin[6]) The Janowski Variation, which gained some interest in 2021 after being adopted by World Champion Magnus Carlsen, threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense. The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4 in the Three Knight's Variation. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues: 5.cxd5 cxd4 6.Qxd4 exd5 7.e4 dxe4 8.Qxc4 Kxd8+. This line has been played by top grandmasters such as Wesley So and Magnus Carlsen aiming for a draw. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5.[19] Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match. The Three Knights Variation is also a popular line.
B17: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. It is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886. The opening is classified as a Semi-Open Game, like the Sicilian Defence and French Defence, although it is more solid and less dynamic than either of those openings. The Classical Variation is played by Lev Milman and Joseph Fang in Foxwoods Open 2005. It is generally considered somewhat unsound, though world championship challenger and former world championship candidate David Bronstein has employed it with some success. More popular recently are variations with Black castling kingside and even leaving his king in the centre. These variations can be sharp and dynamic. Black has opted for an inferior pawn structure and a practical of castling queens, while gaining dynamic compensation in the form of the open g-file. The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? of the Bronstein–Larsen Variation. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3, somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. Black has the option of 5...Nf6 or 5...e6. The Retreat Line 4...Bh5 is playable but Black must be careful. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Other lines include 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5) and 2...d5 3.exd5 cxd5 4. Ne5!?, sometimes referred to as the Apocalypse Attack. The worst response by white to the Cara-Kann defence is g3. White's response on the 3rd move can keep win/loss/draw chances (with d4 or Nc3) or increase draw chances ( with c3) Finnish Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 4.e5 Bg7 5.f4 h5Campomanes Attack: 1, e4 c5 2, c6 3, d5 4, Nc3 5, Nf3 6, Nxf6 7, Bg6 8, Nd7 9, Bd3 10, Qxd3. Classical Variation with 7...Nd7. Spassky Variation. Karpov/Steinitz Variation; Kasparov–Fischer Attack.
B28: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. The Sicilian is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move. Opening 1.d4 is a statistically more successful opening for White because of the high success rate of the Sicilian defence against 1. e4. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical, and Scheveningen. The critical test of Black's move order is 5.c4, the Maróczy Bind, which White hopes to cramp Black's position by impeding the ...d7–5–b5 thrusts. White's most popular move for White is 5.Bd3. The Four Knights Variation is mainly used as a way of getting into the main line Sveshnikov Variation. Black's options are similar to those for 2.Nf3, along with ...e6 and ...d6. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is based on the idea that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" Modern players would consider this notion naive. The opening is named after the city of St. Petersburg. There are many other Sicilian openings, including the Najdorf Variation and the Tal Gambit Declined. It has been the subject of numerous books, includings the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings.

The Caro Kann Defence has been described as "the most successful defence in the history of chess" The opening is named after the inventor of chess, Charles Caro, who died in 1908. B87: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. It is named after Giulio Cesare Polerio, who wrote about it in 1594. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have used the defence. The Sicilian has become the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is 2...d6 which prepares ...Nf6 to attack the e-pawn without letting White push it to e5. Black usually plays 6...e6 to limit the range of White's bishop. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. The entire variation up to 8...b5 is referred to as the Chelyabinsk Variation. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is based on the idea that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" Modern players would consider the notion that this is naive. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. There are also Sicilian Variations, including the Najdorf Variation. D25: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense) It is not considered a true gambit, because the pawn is either regained, or can only be held unprofitably by Black. It was mentioned in literature as early as the 15th century, but the 1886 World Chess Championship between Wilhelm Steinitz and Johannes Zukertort introduced the first modern ideas in this opening. White can try to establish a strong pawn centre with 3.e4, an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation is an uncommon line that focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. The old main line 7.Qe2 allows ...b5, and theory holds that Black can equalise against it. The main modern preference is the retreat 7.Bb3, so that 7...b5 can be met with 8.a4. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4, but the early development of the queen allows Black to win time by harassing it. 3...Nc6 leads to a standard line in the Chigorin Defense. 3.Nc3 is the standard opening for White in the Queen's Gambit.
B73: The Sicilian Defence is the most commonly used opening by grandmasters. It is based on 1.e4, with 3.d4 and 5.Nc3 being the most common moves. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical and Scheveningen. The game becomes a race between White's kingside attack and Black's queenside counterattack. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. The Kasparov Gambit was played twice in the World Chess Championship in 1985, but virtually disappeared from master chess after the game Karpov–Van der Wiel praxis in 1986. Black usually plays 6...e6 (ECO B88 transposed) to limit the range of White's bishop. The Sicilian Defence is also known as the Tal Gambit Declined. It is the first of a number of different opening systems. White can play 2.Nf3 without intending to follow up with 3.d4. Black should counter immediately in the centre by 2...Nf6 or 2...d5. Black's best reply is 2... d5 3.exd5 Nf6! The modern main line runs 2. nc3 Nc6 3.f4 g6 4.nf3 Bg7. The Four Knights Variation is mainly used as a way of getting into the main line Sveshnikov Variation. Black has three main moves: 4...Nc6 (the Taimanov Variation), 4...a6 ( the Kan Variation) and 4 ... nf6.
B74: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. Black has three main options after 2.Nf3: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. It is considered to be the best of the irregular defences to 1...P-K4 and 1...e5. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. Black's ...e5 push seems anti-positional: it has made the d6-pawn backward and the d5-square weak. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is named after the Sicilian town of Sveshnikov. White's strongest reply is to chase the knight by 3.e5 Nd5 4.Nc3 and now (a) 4...Nxc3. Black's best reply is 2...d5 3.exd5 Nf6!, the Tal Gambit. D22: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6. Black usually allows the pawn to be recaptured and uses the time expended to play against White's centre. The opening was mentioned in literature as early as the 15th century. Wilhelm Steinitz and Johannes Zukertort introduced the first modern ideas in this opening in 1886. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation is an uncommon line that focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. The old main line 7.Qe2 allows ...b5, and theory holds that Black can equalise against it. A typical continuation is then 4.Bxc4 exd4 5.exd4, leading to an isolated queen's pawn position. An opening trap where Black tries clinging onto the pawn was pointed out by Alessandro Salvio Salvio in 1604. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4, but the early development of the queen allows Black to win time by harassing it. This line is rarely played. 3...Nc6 leads to a standard line in the Chigorin Defense. 3.Nc3 is a move in the Queen's Gambit.
B80: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1. e4 c5. It is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. The move 4...NaNa is a close relative of the 4...e5 move used by Louis-Charles de Bourdonnais in his 1834 match against Alexander McDonnell. The Kasparov Gambit was played twice in the 1985 World Chess Championship, but virtually virtually no one played it. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. The opening is named after the city of Sicilian, where the tournament took place in 1914. Black's move 2...e6 gives priority to developing the dark-squared bishop. White's strongest reply is to chase the knight by 3.e5 Nd5 4.Nc3 and now (a) 4...Nxc3. The Sicilian defence is also known as the Tal Gambit Declined or the Najdorf Variation. There are also other Sicilian defences, such as the Sicilian Sveshnikov and the Sicillian Svetlana. The defence is often called the "Sicilian Defen" and is often classified under B20 through B99.
B89: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to use the Sicilian. About 80% of Master-level games begin with 2.Nf3, after which there are three main options for Black: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. Lines where White then plays 3.d4 are collectively known as the Open Sicilian, and result in extremely complex positions. The opening was popular for much of the nineteenth century. It fell out of favour when some of the world's leading players rejected it. The Sicilian has become the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. The opening is named after the city of Sicilian, where the tournament took place. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. The Najdorf Variation is the most common variation. It is the second most popular Sicilian after the Sveshnikov Variation. It has been called the most difficult Sicilian to play. It can be played in a variety of ways, incl. 4...a6 ( the Kan Variation) and 4 ...Nf6. Black has: 6...Ne4?! 7.Qg4! Nxc3 8.Qxg7 Rf8 9.a3 Nb5+. The Rossolimo Variation, 3.Bb5, is a well-respected alternative to 3.d4.
D14: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. The theory of the Slav is very extensive and well-developed. There are three main variations: the "Pure" Slav, the "Main Line Slav" and the "Semi-Slav Defense" The Exchange Variation was once described as "the system that takes the fun out of playing the Slav" for Black. Black often chooses the order 2...e6 followed by 3...Bf5 to avoid the possibility of a symmetrical position. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also play 4.e3 when it was thought Black could no longer play the "Pure" Slav with 4...Bf5 (and had to choose between 4...e6 or 4...a6) due to 5.cxd5 cxd5 6.Qb3. 5.e3 is a solid choice known as the Alekhine Variation. Black's main move is 5...Bf5. Play can proceed 5...b5 6.a4 b47.Na2 e6 8.Bxc47.Nb1 Ba6 9.bxc3 Bxf1 10.Nxf1 bxc3. The Czech Variation can be considered the main line. White can also play 10.Qf3 and force a draw. Black can try either 6...Nbd7 7.Nxc4 Qc7 8.g3 e5 (known as the Carlsbad Variation) or 7...Nb6 or 6...e6.
B42: The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. It is often used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is 2...d6 which prepares ...Nf6 to attack the e-pawn without letting White push it to e5. The game usually continues 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical and Scheveningen. The rare Kupreichik Variation (5...Bd7) may transpose to a number of independent lines. Black develops the bishop to g7 in the Accelerated Dragon. The move 4...e5 has had a long history; Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourd used it in his short matches against Alexander McDonnell in 1834. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is based on the Sicilian Opening. There are several variations, including the Najdorf Variation. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings classifies it under the codes B20 through B99. The most important variations are the Rossolimo, Kalashnikov, Sveshnikov and Accelerated Dragon. White's most popular fifth move for White is 5.Bd3, when after 5...Bc5 6.Nb3 Black can either retreat 6...Be7 or 6...Ba7. Black has: 6...Ne4?! 7.Qg4! Nxc3 8.Qxg7 Rf8 9.a3 Nb5+ 10.axb4 Nxd4 11.Bg5 Qb6 12.Bh6 Qxb4+ 13.c3 Nf5 14.cxb4 Nxg 7 15.Bxg8. The Sicilian is considered to be the most difficult of the three chess openings to play.
B45: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. The Sicilian opens with 2.Nf3, followed by 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical and Scheveningen. The rare Kupreichik Variation (5...Bd7) may transpose to one of more common variations such as the Classical or Dragon. The Sveshnikov Variation was pioneered by Evgeny Sveschnikov and Gennadi Timoshchenko in the 1970s. Emanuel Lasker played it in his world championship match against Carl Schlechter in the 1950s. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most difficult chess openings to learn. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.Nf3. Black's best reply is 2...d5 3.exd5 Nf6!, the Tal Gambit. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4...nf3 Bg7. White has the option of 6.c4, which solidifies control of d5 and clamps down on ...b5. Black has: 6...Ne4?! 7.Qg4! Nxc3 8.Qxg7 Rf8 9.a3 Nb5+ 10.axb4 Nxd4 11.Bg5 Qb6 12.Bh6 Qxb4+ 13.c3 nf5 14.cXg7 15.Bxg 7.
D13: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. The theory of the Slav is very extensive and well-developed. The Slav has been adopted by Anand, Ivanchuk, Lautier, Short, and other top grandmasters. Vladimir Kramnik used the Slav Defense in six of the eight games that he played as Black in the 2006 World Championship. Black often chooses the order 2...e6 followed by 3...c6 to avoid the possibility of a totally symmetrical position. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also play 4.e3 when it was thought Black could no longer play the "Pure" Slav with 4...Bf5 (and had to choose between 4...e6 or 4...a6) 5.e3 is a solid choice known as the Alekhine Variation. Play can proceed 5...b5 6.a4 b47.Na2 e6 8.Bxc47.Nb1 Ba6, 8.Nbd2 c3 9.bxc3 Bxf1 10.Nxf1 bxc3. With 5...Bf5, Black prevents 6.e4 with the idea of 7...Nb4. Black can try either 6...Nbd7 7.Nxc4 Qc7 8.g3 e5 (known as the Carlsbad Variation) or 7...nb6 or 6...e6.
B11: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. It is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886. It allows Black to circumvent enormous bodies of theory in 1. e4 openings such as the Ruy Lopez and the Sicilian Defence. Black has less mobility and can lag in development. The Classical Variation is one of the most popular. It is also known as the Smyslov Variation or the Karpov Variation. More popular recently are variations with Black castling kingside and even leaving his king in the centre. These variations can be sharp and dynamic. The famous last game of the Deep Blue versus Garry Kasparov rematch was played in this very line. Black often plays the aggressive 5.Ng5!? where Black's development is brought into question as well as the positional weakness. The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? of the Bronstein–Larsen Variation. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3, somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. 3...e6 is probably the most solid response, preparing to exploit the dark squares via ...c5, though 3....g6 has been tried by Yasser Seirawan. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Black may play 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5) or 2...d5 3.exd5 cxd5 4.Ne5!?, sometimes referred to as the Apocalypse Attack. Other lines are ineffective or doubtful. The worst response by white to the Cara-Kann defence is g3. D40: The Queen's Gambit Declined (or QGD) is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. In the Orthodox Line, the fight for the tempo revolves around White's efforts to play all other useful developing moves prior to playing Bd3. Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening, which often leads to one or the other side accepting isolated or hanging pawns in exchange for dynamic compensation. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4; or 4.E3 which may lead to the Stonewall Dutch after ...f5 or transpose to the Semi-Slav. 3...Bb4 (the Accelerated Ragozin[6]) White has various options to avoid this transposition. The Janowski Variation, which gained some interest in 2021 after being adopted by World Champion Magnus Carlsen, threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4 in the Three Knight's Variation. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. This line has been played by top grandmasters such as Wesley So, Anish Giri, and Magnus Carlsen aiming for a draw. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5.[19] Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match. The Three Knights Variation is also a popular line.
B16: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. The opening is named after the English player Horatio Caro and the Austrian player Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886. It is classified as a Semi-Open Game, like the Sicilian Defence and French Defence, although it is more solid and less dynamic than either of those openings. The Classical Variation is one of the most popular. It is sometimes called the Steinitz Variation or the Smyslov Variation. The Karpov Variation was played by the twelfth world champion Anatoly Karpovsky. The Caro–Kann Variation has been played by Lars Benten and David Bronstein. Black can castle kingside and even leave his king in the centre in some variations. White can also play the 5.Ng5!? where Black's development is brought into question as well as the positional weakness. The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? of the Bronstein–Larsen Variation. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3, somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. Black's logical and probably best reply is 3...Bg4. After 4...Nf6 or 5...e6, the Retreat Line 4...Bh5 is playable but Black must be careful. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Black may play 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5) or 2...d5 3.exd5 cxd5 4.Ne5!?, sometimes referred to as the Apocalypse Attack. Other lines include 2.d3, 2.b3, the Euwe Attack, 2b4, the Labahn Attack and 2.g4. The Caro-Kann Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is named after the American chess master Caro Kann. There are several variations on the opening, including the Bronstein–Larsen Variation and the Spassky Variation. There is also a variation on the Karpov/Steinitz Variation called the Tiviakov/Fischer Attack. The opening is played with the Sicilian Defence, which opens with the move N-E-F-C.
B29: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. It is named after Giulio Cesare Polerio, who wrote about it in 1594. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is 2...d6 which prepares ...Nf6 to attack the e-pawn without letting White push it to e5. Black can then choose between four major variations. The Sicilian has become the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. The move 4e5 has a long history; Louis-Charles Mahéonnais used it in his matches against Alexander McDonnell in 1834. The Kasparov Gambit was played twice in the World Chess Championship in 1985. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. The opening is named after the city of Sicilian. There are also openings named after other places in the world. The Sicilian defence is considered to be the most difficult of all chess openings. White can play 2.Nf3 without intending to follow up with 3.d4. Black has: 6...Ne4?! 7.Qg4! Nxc3 8.Qxg7 Rf8 9.a3 Nb5+ 10.axb4 Nxd4 11.Bg5 Qb6 12.Bh6 Qxb4+ 13.c3 Nf5 14.cxb4 Nxg 7 15.Bxg8.
B20: The Sicilian Defence is the most commonly used opening in chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. The earliest recorded notes on the Sicillian Defence date back to the late 16th century by the Italian chess players Giulio Polerio and Gioachino Greco. The Sicilian was developed in 1813 by the English master Jacob Henry Sarratt. It fell out of favour in the later part of the nineteenth century, when some of the world's leading players rejected it. After 1.e4 c5 there are three main options for Black: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical and Scheveningen. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings. It is named after the Sicilian city of Sveshnikov. The opening is based on the 1.e4 Sicilian Variation. It has been described as the "most difficult opening to learn" in the history of chess. White's strongest reply is to chase the knight by 3.e5 Nd5 4.Nc3 and now (a) 4...Nxc3. Black has: 6...Ne4?! 7.Qg4! Nxc3 8.Qxg7 Rf8 9.a3 Nb5+. The Rossolimo Variation, 3.Bb5, is a well-respected alternative to 3.d4. White can prevent this by 5.Nb5 d6.
D82: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4. If White does not take the d5-pawn, Black may eventually play ...dxc4, when a White response of e4 again leads to the same pawn structure. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school of chess held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variant with White, often involving an early Rb1 to remove the rook from the sensitive a1–h8 diagonal. Another, relatively recently developed system involves quickly playing Be3, Qd2 and Rc1 or Rd1 to fortify White's centre. The Grünfeld Gambit is a variation of the Exchange Variation. White can accept the gambit by playing 6.cxd5 Nxd5 7.Nxd5 Qxd5 8.Bxc7, or decline it with 6.Qb3 or 6.Rc1, to which Black responds with 6...c5. Systems in which White delays the development Nc3 are known as the Neo-Grünfield Defence (ECO code D70–D79) Typical move orders are 1.d4 Nf6 2.g3 g6 3.c4 d5 or, more commonly, 1. d4 nf6. Chessgames: Neo-Grünfeld 3.f3 is a version of the classic game 3.g3. The game is based on the rules of the 3.4-3.5-3-3 game. It is played using the following rules: 3. f3, 3. g3 and 3. h3. It can also be played with the notation 3.2, which is the equivalent of 3.5. It has been released in Germany, Israel and the United States.

It has the highest score in the history of the game. It is also the most difficult to play. It can be played in any number of ways. The most popular is 3.3.
B27: The Sicilian Defence is the most commonly used opening in chess. It is designed to give Black the most chances against 1.e4. After 2.Nf3 there are three main options for Black: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. The game usually continues 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3. B18: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. It is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886. A58: Benko Gambit is a chess opening characterised by the move 3...b5 in the Benoni Defence. Black sacrifices a pawn for enduring queenside pressure. The idea of sacrificing a pawn with ...b5 and ...a6 is quite old. In many countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the opening is known as the Volga Gambit (Russian: Волжкий гамбит). This name is derived from an article about 3... b5!? by B. Argunow written in Kuibyshev (Samara since 1991), Russia. The Pal Benko gambit is a chess opening named after the eponym. It is a popular opening at amateur level, where it is considered to offer Black good practical chances of playing for a win. Many of the world's strongest players have used it at one time or another, including former world champions Viswanathan Anand, Garry Kasparov, Veselin Topalov, and Mikhail Tal. The most popular line is 4...bxc4, the Sosonko Accepted, which often leads to sharp and sacrificial lines.
A67: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5 and other openings in which Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player to have successfully used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4 in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time.
E03: The Catalan Opening is a chess opening where White plays d4 and c4 and fianchettoes the white bishop on g2. In the Catalan, White adopts a combination of the Queen's Gambit and Réti Opening. Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. The Catalan derives its name from Catalonia, after tournament organisers at the 1929 Barcelona tournament asked Savielly Tartakower to create a new variation in homage to the area's chess history. A93: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. It is an aggressive and unbalancing opening, resulting in the lowest percentage of draws among the most common replies to 1.d4. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and his challenger, David Bronstein, played it in their 1951 World Championship match. The Stonewall Dutch enjoyed a resurgence of interest in the 1980s and 1990s, when leading grandmasters used it. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839 against von der Lasa, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines, although Black must then be ready to play the French Defence if White continues 2.e4. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) has twenty codes for the Dutch Defence, A80 through A99. C99: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5ECOC60–C99 OriginGöttingen manuscript, 1490Named afterRuy López de Segura, Libro del Ajedrez, 1561ParentKing's Knight OpeningSynonym(s)Spanish Opening Spanish Game Spanish Torture [colloquial] Due to the difficulty for Black in achieving equality, a common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish torture" 3...a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Ruyopez. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911. Boris Spassky has a career-plus score with the Breyer. The Chigorin Variation has declined in popularity because Black must spend some time bringing his offside knight on a5 back into the game. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. The Classical Defence or Cordel Defence (ECO C64), 3...Bc5 is possibly the oldest defence to the Ruy Lopez. The Berlin Defence, 3...Nf6, has long had a reputation for solidity and drawishness. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4.
A94: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack in the middlegame on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and challenger David Bronstein played it in their 1951 World Championship match. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839 against von der Lasa, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines, although Black must then be ready to play the French Defence if White continues 2.e4. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) has twenty codes for the Dutch Defence, A80 through A99. Nf3, 6.Nc3 Qe8 (Ilyin–Genevsky Variation) A96: 1, d4, f5; 2, c4; 3, Nf4; 4, e4; 5, e5; 6, e6; 7, e7; 8, e8; 9, e9; 10, e3; 11, e2; 12, e1; 13, b1; 14, b2; 15, b3; 16, b4, b5.
E04: The Catalan Opening is a chess opening where White plays d4 and c4 and fianchettoes the white bishop on g2. The Catalan derives its name from Catalonia, after tournament organisers at the 1929 Barcelona tournament asked Savielly Tartakower to create a new variation. Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. The Open Catalan has been a favorite of Anatoly Karpov and Efim Geller. C52: The Italian Game is a family of chess openings beginning with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4ECOC50–C59 Origin15th or 16th centuryParentKing's Knight Opening. Black's two main options are 3...Bc5, the Giuoco Piano, and 3...Nf6, the Two Knights Defense. It is part of the large family of Open Games or Double King's Pawn Games. 3...Nd4 (Blackburne Shilling Gambit) is a false gambit expectant upon White falling into the trap of capturing Black's undefended pawn (4.Nxe5?! Qg5) After 3...Qf6?! 4.Nc3 Nge7 5.Nb5 White has a clear advantage (Unzicker).3...h6. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time. However, it has no immediate refutation and has been tried by Czech grandmaster Pavel Blatny.
A60: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow" It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5 and other openings in which Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player to have successfully used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4, in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. Black appears to retain the advantage against both setups. A69: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow" It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5, and later with 1. d4 Nf6 2.c 4 c5 and other openings in which Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. C90: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The theory of the Ruyopez is the most extensively developed of all Open Games. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. After 4.Bxc6, Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. Black has doubled pawns, but has the bishop pair. In the Exchange Variation, White damages Black's pawn structure, gaining a ready-made long-term plan of playing d4 ...exd4 Qxf4. The main line of 7...d6, 8.Nd5 Na5 9.Nxe7 Qxe7 10. d3 0-0 is a common idea. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–ZaitseV Variation) was advocated by Igor Zait sev, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911. The Schliemann Defence or Schlieman–Jaenisch Gambit (ECO C63), 3...f5 is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost.
C64: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5ECOC60–C99OriginGöttingen manuscript, 1490Named afterRuy López de Segura, Libro del Ajedrez, 1561. Due to the difficulty for Black in achieving equality, a common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Alternatives to Closed Defence described in this section are:4.Bxc6 (Exchange Variation)4.Ba44...b5 (Graz Defence)4...Bc5 4...f5 (Schliemann Defence Deferred) 4...d6 (Modern Steinitz Defence) The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. White plays 9.d3 intending to later advance to d4 under favourable circumstances. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost. The Berlin Defence, 3...Nf6, has long had a reputation for solidity and drawishness. White's most important continuations after 4...Bc5 are 5.0-0, 5.Bxc6, and 5.c3.
A56: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow" In 1825 Aaron Reinganum published a book entitled Ben-Oni oder die Vertheidigungen gegen die Gambitzüge im Schache. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5 and other openings in which Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4 in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. E32: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxf4 Qc7 (Main Variation) The Main Variation was enormously popular in the 1950s, but the name has become increasingly inappropriate. The Rubinstein Variation is one of the most popular versions of the game. Black will play a quick ...e5 to pressurize d4. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight, thus avoiding the doubled pawns. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6), while White will try to pursue a strategy of gaining queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6). In the former case, the bishop will eventually retreat to e7 and Black will set up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. After 5...Qxd5, Black can either recapture with the pawn or defend with the queen. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. B90-99: The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular opening lines in chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is 2...d6 which prepares ...Nf6 to attack the e-pawn without letting White push it to e5. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical, and Scheveningen. In the Dragon Variation, Black fianchettoes a bishop on the h8–a1 diagonal. White's most dangerous try against the Dragon is the Yugoslav Attack, characterised by 6.Be3 Bg7 7.f3 0-0 8.Qd2 Nc6 and 9.Bc4. The Sveshnikov Variation has become very popular in master level chess. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. The opening is named after the city of Sicilian, where it was played in the Grand International Masters' Tournament at St. Petersburg 1914. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. Black's best reply is 2...d5 3.exd5 Nf6!, the Tal Gambit. The Four Knights Variation is mainly used as a way of getting into the main line Sveshnikov Variation. The Pin Variation (also called the Sicilian Counter-Attack) is considered theoretically suspect, but if White is unprepared the tactics can be difficult to calculate at the board.
E35: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch in the early 20th century. It can also transpose into lines of the Queen's Gambit or Queen's Indian Defence. Black's delay in committing to a pawn structure makes it a very flexible defence to 1.d4. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bg5 Bb7. 11.Ne5, 11.Rc1 and 11.Qe2 are all good moves for White. The Rubinstein is one of the most popular chess games in the world. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation. Black will play a quick ...e5 to pressurize d4. White will try to build up a strong centre with f3 and e4. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. Two lines where White does this (following 4.e3 0-0) are:5.Ne2 (Reshevsky Variation) and 5.Bd3 d5 6. Ne2 (Modern Variation). 4...c5 is a well-known move in chess. There are two major variations particular to 4... c5:5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6), while White will try to pursue a strategy of gaining queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are all common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century. It was the discovery of 12.Qd2! which revived this line for White. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. 4...d5 transposes to the Ragozin Defence of the Queen's Gambit Declined and 4...b6. The Nimzo/Queen's Indian hybrid line is the most common move that stays within Nimzo-Indian territory. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside. A51: The Budapest Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e5. The first known game with the gambit is Adler–Maróczy (played in Budapest in 1896) The Hungarian players István Abonyi, Zsigmond Barász and Gyula Breyer further developed the opening. It enjoyed a rise in popularity in the early 1920s, but nowadays is rarely played at the top level. Black usually looks to have an aggressive game or cripple White's pawn structure. White does not try to defend his e5-pawn and keep his material advantage, but instead he concentrates on building an imposing pawn centre. Black can try to exploit weaknesses with the manoeuvres Bf4–d2–c3, Ng1–e2–g3–h5 and h2–h4. The Budapest Gambit is a variation of the Queen's Gambit. It is a move that involves pawn advances on the queenside, resulting in the creation of a weak pawn for Black, then winning this weak pawn. Black mates with either 31.Kf5 g6+ 32.KF6 Bd4 mate, or 31. Kf3 Rf2 mate. The move was referenced in season 28, episode 15, of The Simpsons, in an episode called "The Cad and the Hat" White must develop quietly with moves like Nc3/Nf3/E3/e3/Be2, and prepare several sacrificial ideas on e3 or f2. White cannot reply 5.Bd2 as he would lose the bishop pair and Black would easily regain the e5-pawn with Nc6/Qe7/0-0/Re8.
C63: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. The most commonly played third move for Black is the Morphy Defence, 3...a6, a move that forces White to retreat or exchange for Black's knight. The opening remains the most commonly used amongst the open games in master play. It has been adopted by almost all players during their careers, many have played it with both colours. The Riga Variation, 6...exd4, is considered inferior; the main line runs 7.Re1 d5 8.Nxd4 Bd6! 9.Nxc6 Bxh2+! 10.Kh1! (10.Kxh1 Qh4+ 11.Kg1 Qxf2+) The main line begins with 9.exd5 Nxd5 (9...e4?!, the Herman Steiner variation, is considered weaker) 10.Nxe5 Nxe5 11.Rxe5 c6 (Marshall's original moves, 11...Nf6, and 11...Bb7 are considered inferior, but have also yielded good results) The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–ZaitseV Variation) was advocated by Igor ZaitSEv, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns.
C97: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. The Morphy Defence is the most commonly played third move for Black. White's objective is to spoil Black's pawn structure. Black can respond in a wide variety of ways to White's third move. The theory of the Ruyopez is most extensively developed of all Open Games, with some lines having been analysed well beyond move thirty. The main line leads to unbalanced endgames which are difficult to play for both sides, though with a strong drawing tendency. The Schliemann Defence Deferred, 3...a6 4.Ba4 f5, is rarely seen, with practically its only top-level appearance being in the 1974 Candidates Final. The Chigorin Variation has declined in popularity because Black must spend some time bringing his offside knight on a5 back into the game. The Kholmov Variation, 9...Be6, was popular in the 1980s but is now played less often at the master level. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4.
E61: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast. It originated in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. In the United States the name was changed in the early twentieth century to Cornish. A white variant, the White Cornish, was developed there at about the same time. The Indian Game was bred as a gamecock, but was not successful as a fighting bird. It was found to be a good meat breed, and was used for cross-breeding with established meat breeds.
A05: The King's Indian Attack is a chess opening system where White adopts the setup more commonly seen being played by Black in the King's India Defence. The King'sIndianAttack is a closed, strategic opening that presents its practitioner with common themes and tactics and a comfortable middlegame against various defences. Black is effectively a move down in a theoretically unimportant line of the King’s Indian Defence. Black's most common plan involves the central pawn push e4–e5, leading to a central bind, kingside space, and practical attacking chances against the black king. After 1.e4 e6, the game might typically proceed as follows: 4.Ngf3 Nf6 5.g3 Nc6 6.Bg2 Be7 7.0-0 0-0 8.Re1 (see diagram in previous section) White will now look to play e4–e5, cramping Black, and then proceed with moves such as Nf1, Bf4, Qe2, h4, N1h2 (or Ne3), h5, g4 (or Ng4) The Kings Indian Attack setup is also sometimes employed against the Caro–Kann Defence. C08: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The McCutcheon Variation is named for John Lindsay McCutheon of Philadelphia (1857–1905), who brought the variation to public attention when he used it to defeat World Champion Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. The Burn Variation, the Morozevich Variation and the Advance Variation are the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. Black's natural French Defence move 6...c5 runs into 7.Bxe7 when Black must either move the king with 7...Kxe7 or allow 7...Qxe7 8.Nb5! The Advance Variation has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings includes an alphanumeric classification system for openings that is widely used in chess literature. Codes C00 to C19 are the French Defence, broken up in the following way (all apart from C00 start with the mov): C00-C19: C00, C01-C02, C04-C05, C06-C07, C08-C09, C10-C11, C12-C13, C14-C14, C15-C15, C16-C16, C17-C18, C19-C20, C21-C21, C22-C22, C23-C24, C24-C25, C26-C26, C27-C28, C28-C29, C29-C30, C30-C31, C31-C3, C4-C5, C6-C6, C7-C8, C8-C9, C9-C10, C11-C12, C3-C4, C5-C7, D5-D6, D7-D8, D8-D
E92: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) White's major third move options are 3.Nc3, 3.nf3 or 3.g3. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings classifies the opening under codes E60 through E99. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and is content to play for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The Classical Defence is 5...0-0 6.Be3 e5. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6) The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. The SäMisch Gambit is a pawn sacrifice. The Four Pawns Attack continues with 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f4 0-0 6.Nf3. With their fifth move, White erects a massive centre at the price of falling behind in development. From this 6...c5 is the main line. 6...Nbd7 and 6...Na6 (Judit Polgár's move) are also seen. 9...Re8 can be justified with solid play. Black often repels the bishop with ...h6 giving them the option of a later g5, though in practice this is a weakening move. White has other setups, such as Nf3 and h3 and Nge2 (with or without Bd3), but these are currently not as popular at the grandmaster level. 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. One of the most famous King's Indian games was a brilliancy by the late Ukrainian-American grandmaster Eduard Gufeld, who called it his "Mona Lisa" E86 King's Indian, Sämisch, Orthodox, 7.Nge2 c6E87 King'sIndian, SÜmisch,. Orthodox,  7.d5 c6, 7...Nbd7, 8.Re1, Main line. E90 King's Iraqi, 5.Nf3, Kazakh variation, 6.Be2, Classical Variation. E93 King's Italian, Petrosian system, Main Line, 7 Nbd 7, 9.Ne1. E96 King's Russian, Orthodox,. Aronin–Taimanov Variation (Yugoslav Attack / Mar del Plata Variation)
A02: Bird's Opening is a standard flank opening. It is named after 19th century English player Henry Bird. Black may challenge White's plan to control e5 immediately by playing From's Gambit (1...e5). The From Gambit is notoriously double-edged and should only be played after significant study. Black's most common response is 1...d5, when the game can take on the character of a Dutch Defence (1.d4 f5) with colours reversed. White will then often either fianchetto their king's bishop with Nf3, g3, Bg2, and 0–0 with a reversed Leningrad Dutch. Emanuel Lasker introduced 4...g5 in the game Bird–Lasker, Newcastle upon Tyne, 1892. International Master (IM) Timothy Taylor, in his 2005 book on the Bird's, recommends 3.Nc3! Nxe5 4.d4 intending 5.e4, rather than 3.nf3?! g5! when Black stands well. After the normal 2...d6 3.exd6 Bxd6, White must play 4.Nf3, avoiding 4.c3?? Qh4+ 5.g3 Qxg3+ 6.hxg 3 Bxg2! or 4...Nf6, threatening 5...Ng4. The offbeat 1...b6!? is also known, and more soundly based than the same move after 1.e4 or 1.d4. The Swiss Gambit was named by Alexander Wagner (1868–1942), a Polish chess player and openings analyst who introduced it in the Swiss correspondence game Wagner–Kostin, 1910–11. Another offbeat try is Martin Appleberry's 1...Nh6!?, also known as the Horsefly, which exploits the closed c1-h6 diagonal. 1.f4 ranks sixth in popularity in Chessgames.com's database. It is less than one-twentieth as popular as the mirror image English Opening (1.c4) The move slightly weakens White's king's position. Black's most successful response to Bird's Opening in the 1600-2200 rating range is e5, where Black's win percentage is 50-46%, but that evens to 48-48% when White plays 2.fxe5. The five more popular openings are still substantially more successful for White. Chess is a popular game of chess. Chess tournaments include the World Chess Championship and the FIDE Grand Prix. Chess is an important part of the arts and culture. chess is also used in music, film, and literature. Chess has its roots in the ancient city of Budapest in Hungary. Chess was first played in the 13th century by Peter Boltzmann in what is now known as the Budapest Gambit. The opening of a chess game is often referred to as the first game.
C30: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4. It is infrequently seen at master level today, as Black has several methods to obtain equality, but is still popular at amateur level. It was one of the most popular openings until the late 19th century, when improvements in defensive technique led to its decline in popularity. The main reason is that it is hard to gain an advantage with White's pawn. After 2...exf4, the two main continuations for White are 3.Nf3 (King's Knight's Gambit) and 3.Bc4 (Bishop'sGambit) Black's two main approaches are to attempt to hold on to the pawn with ...g5, or to return the pawn in order to facilitate development. The Kieseritzky Gambit, 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5, is considered by modern writers such as John Shaw and Joseph Gallagher to be the main line after 3...g5. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. The move has received renewed attention following its recommendation by John Shaw in his 2013 book on the King's Gambit. A well-known trap here is 4...g4 5.Ne5 Qh4+ 6.g3 fxg3 7.Qxg4 g2+. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6) was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. The MacLeod Defense, 3...Nc6, is named after Nicholas MacLeod. The Bishop's Gambit allows 3...Bc4+ 4...Qh4+ but White loses the right to castle. Black's most popular option, it attracted some attention in 2020 when Ding Liren used it to beat Magnus Carlsen in an online tournament. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit, as he says that Black is better in all variations. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. It runs 1.e4 e5 2.f4 d5 3.exd5 e4, in which Black sacrifices a pawn in return for quick and easy development. 2...Nc6, advocated by Tony Miles; 2...d6, which is the way the King’s Gambit was declined the first known time it was played. The greedy 2...Qf6 (known as the Nordwalde Variation), intending 3...Qxf4, is considered dubious. 2...Nf6 3.fxe5 Nxe4 4.Nf3 Ng5! 5.d4 Nxf3+ 6.Qxf3 Qh4+ 7.Qf2 Qxf2+ 8.Kxf2 with a small endgame advantage.
E66: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) White's major third move options are 3.Nc3, 3.nf3 or 3.g3. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings classifies it under the codes E60 through E99. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and is content to play for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6). This can transpose to the Modern Benoni after 5...0-0 6.Bg5 c5 7.d5 e6. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. The Averbakh Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5. The Fianchetto Variation starts with 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.nf3 Bf3 4.g3 d6 6.0-0. The Four Pawns Attack continues with 3. nc3 bg7 6.f4 0-1 6.Nf3 6.Na6 6...c5 is the most aggressive method for White. White has other setups, such as Nf3 and h3 and Nge2 (with or without Bd3), but these are currently not as popular at the grandmaster level. 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. One of the most famous King's Indian games was a brilliancy by the late Ukrainian-American grandmaster Eduard Gufeld, who called it his "Mona Lisa" Vladimir Bagirov–Eduard Gufeld, USSR championship 1973 "The Mona Lisa" at chessgames.comRetrieved from "https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=King%27s_Indian_Defence&oldid=1" King's Indian, Sämisch, Orthodox, 7.Nge2 c6, 7...Nbd7, 8.Re1, 9.Ne1. Saemisch System.
E59: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It can also transpose into lines of the Queen's Gambit or Queen's Indian Defence. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4, is played at all levels and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Ba5 9.Bg5 Bb7 10.Rc1 and 11.Qe2 are good moves for White. The Rubinstein is one of the most popular chess games. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. Two lines where White does this (following 4.e3 0-0) are:5.Ne2 (Reshevsky Variation) or 5.Bd3 d5 6. Ne2 (Modern Variation). 4...c5 is the most common move in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4... c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo-Indian game, though it was superseded by the Rubinstein Variation. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. It is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov and former Women's Champion Nona Gaprindashvili. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 6 Bd3 b6 (Classical Fianchetto/Tal Variation) E51 – 4-4.e2 5.F3 d4 5.E4 d5 5.e4 4.F5 d5 7.Bxc4 cxd4 9.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc3 10.Bxf4 10.bxf4 (includes Main Variation)[edit]
E50: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response to 4...e5. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Bxc3 dxc3 9.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) The Main Variation was enormously popular in the 1950s, but the name has become increasingly inappropriate. After 4.e3 0-0 White has a huge selection of moves to choose from. Black must be familiar with all of them. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. If Black can prevent White from achieving this, then they will enjoy the better game. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. 4.e3 is a well-known move in chess. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6), while White will try to pursue a strategy of gaining queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are all common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5 or 5... 0-0 6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. 4...d5 transposes to the Ragozin Defence of the Queen's Gambit Declined and 4...b6. The Nimzo/Queen's Indian hybrid line is the most common move that stays within Nimzo-Indian territory. After 6.Nf3 Qf5 7.Qxf5 exf5, Black strengthens his grip on e4 and makes e6 available for the bishop. A34: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen and Ding Liren have employed it during their world championship matches. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5 whereupon even though ...e4 has been delayed, once it is played the defence is classified as a Reversing Sicilian. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. After 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The many different transpositional possibilities available to White make the English a slippery opening for Black to defend against. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. The opening was written by Edward Winter in the late 19th century and is now considered a classic. There are several variations of the opening, including the Fianchetto Line and the Symmetry Line.
