C06: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience, although some lines such as the Winawer Variation can lead to sharp complications. Black's natural French Defence move 6...c5 runs into 7.Bxe7 when Black must either move the king with 7...Kxe7 or allow 7...Qxe7 8.Nb5! The McCutcheon Variation is named for John Lindsay McCutheon of Philadelphia (1857–1905), who brought the variation to public attention when he used it to defeat World Champion Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. The Advance has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. It declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s by GM and prominent opening theoretician Evgeny Sveshnikov. In recent years, it has become nearly as popular as 3. nd2; GM Alexander Grischuk has championed it successfu. Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3 in the early 1990s, before switching back to the traditional 3.nc2. The Advance has been the subject of a number of books, including one written by the legendary Russian chess master Anatoly Kuznetsov, which was published in 2000.
C39: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4, regaining the Gambit pawn. It is infrequently seen at master level today, as Black has several methods to obtain equality, but is still popular at amateur level. It was one of the most popular openings until the late 19th century, when improvements in defensive technique led to its decline in popularity. The Kieseritzky Gambit, 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5, is considered by modern writers to be the main line after 3...g5. Boris Spassky used it to beat Bobby Fischer in a famous game at Mar del Plata in 1960. The Long Whip Variation, 5...h5?! 6.Bc4 Rh7 (or 6...Nh6) is considered old-fashioned and risky, as Black loses a lot of time attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. A well-known trap here is 4...g4 5.Ne5 Qh4+ 6.g3 fxg3 7.Qxg4 g2+? (7.Nxg 4 d5 is about equal) White has strong central control with pawns on d4 and e4. Black is relying on the white king's discomfort to compensate. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. Fischer's analysis of 3...d6, which he called "a high-class waiting move", was published in the American Chess Quarterly in 1960. The MacLeod Defense, 3...Nc6, is named after Nicholas MacLeod. Like Fischer's Defense, it is a waiting move. The Bishop's Gambit, 3.Bc4, is the most important. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit, as he says that Black is better in all variations. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. It runs 1.e4 e5 2.f4 d5 3.exd5 e4, in which Black sacrifices a pawn in return for quick development. The King's Gambit is one of the oldest countergambits in chess. It is considered dubious because 3.exf5 with the threat of Qh5+ gives White a good game. The variation is sometimes named the Pantelidakis Countergambit because GM Larry Evans answered a question about it in Chess Life and Review. White may also offer the gambit in the Bishop's Opening, e.g. 1.e4 e5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.f4, though this is uncommon.
C01: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 e6, 2.d4 d5, 3.Nc3 or 3.e5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience, although some lines such as the Winawer Variation can lead to sharp complications. Black's natural French Defence move 6...c5 runs into 7.Bxe7 when Black must either move the king with 7...Kxe7 or allow 7...Qxe7 8.Nb5! The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was named for John Lindsay McCutchene. The Advance Variation was developed by GM Evgeny Sveshnikov in the 1970s. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings includes an alphanumeric classification system for openings that is widely use. The system is based on a. structure of letters, numbers, and letters of the alphabet. It is also based on an alphabetical list of letters and numbers. The opening structure is called the "Advance Variation" or the "A-V" structure. It has been used in chess for more than 100 years and is still widely used in some parts of the world, such as Russia and the U.S. It was revived in the 1980s by GM and prominent opening theoretician Evgeni SvesHnikov.
A33: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen and Ding Liren have employed it during their world championship matches. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5. All irregular responses such as 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack. Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The many transpositional possibilities available to White make the English a slippery opening for Black to defend against. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. The opening is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. The English Opening was written by Edward Winter in the late 19th century. It is one of the most widely used chess openings in the world. There are a number of variations of the English Opening, including the Fianchetto Line. E68: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) It is a hypermodern opening, where Black deliberately allows White control of the centre with pawns, with the view to subsequently challenge it. The opening is a favourite of former world champions Garry Kasparov and Bobby Fischer. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and is content to play for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. Black will often have at least an equal position if they are able to play ...Nd4. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6) This can transpose to the Modern Benoni after 5...0-0 6.Bg5 c5 7.d5 e6. Black's most popular response is 7.Be3, similar to the Gligoric System. The Four Pawns Attack continues with 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f4 0-0 6.Nf3. With their fifth move, White erects a massive centre at the price of falling behind in development. From this 6...c5 is the main line. Black often repels the bishop with ...h6 giving them the option of a later g5. The most common responses are:6...Nbd7 with 8...exd4. Black intends to claim the centre with ...e7–e5. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. One of the most famous King's Indian games was a brilliancy by the late Ukrainian-American grandmaster Eduard Gufeld, who called it his "Mona Lisa" E86 King's Indian, Sämisch, Orthodox, 7.Nge2 c6E87 King'sIndian, S Ongoing Orthodox, 7...Nbd7, 8.Re1E88 King's Indian, Sämischer, Orthodox Main line 7.d5 c6. E89 King's  Indian, Ornithological, Orthodox. Main line, 5.Nf3 c3, 6.Be2 c2. E90 King's Hindu, Sömisch Orthodox, Main line 6.e3 c2, 6...Nf2 c3. E93 King's India, Petrosian system, Main lines 7...nbd7. E94 King's Indians, Orthodox Variation 7... Nbd7 and 7...Re1. C96: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. Due to the difficulty for Black in achieving equality, a common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" The most commonly played third move for Black is the Morphy Defence, 3...a6, a move that forces White to retreat or exchange for Black's knight. The opening remains the most commonly used amongst the open games in master play; it has been adopted by almost all players. The most common line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Exchange Variation, 4.Bxc6, (ECO C68–C69) White damages Black's pawn structure. The main line begins with 9.exd5 Nxd5 (9...e4?!, the Herman Steiner variation, is considered weaker) 10.Nxe5 Nxe5 c6 (Marshall's original moves, 11...Nf6, and 11...Bb7 are considered inferior, but have also yielded good results) The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. White plays 9.d3 intending to later advance to d4 under favourable circumstances. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911, but there are no known game records in which Breyer employed this line. The Schliemann Defence (ECO C63), 3...f5 is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped.
E34: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response to 4...e5. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Main Variation was enormously popular in the 1950s, but the name has become increasingly inappropriate ever since. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 and 4...Nc6. 1d1 1b2 1b1 2 1b3 1b4 1b5 1b6 1b7 1b8 1b9 1b10 1b11 1b12 1b13 1b14 1b15 1b16 1b17 1b18 1b19 1b20 1b21 1b22 1b23 1b24 1b25 1b26 1b27 1b28 1b29 1b30 1b31 1b32 1b33 1b34 1b36 1b38 1b39 1b40 1b41 1b42 1b44 1b45 1b51 1b52 1b53 1b54 1b55 1b56 1b57 1b58 1b59 1b60 1b61 1b62 1b64 1b65 1b66 1b72 1b73 1b74 1b75 1b76 1b77 1b78 1b79 1b80 1b81 1b82 1b83 1b84 1b85 1b92 1b94 1b90 1b96 1b98 1b99 1b100 1b102 1b103 1b104 1b105 1b106 1b107 1b108 1b110 1b111 1b112 1b113 1b114 1b115 1b120 1b122 1b133 1b138 1b140 1b142
C62: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. The Morphy Defence is the most commonly played third move for Black. White's objective is to spoil Black's pawn structure. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" 3...a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Ruyopez. Black usually plays e-c3 to defend the e-pawn, usually with 5...Bg6. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. White plays 9.d3 intending to later advance to d4 under favourable circumstances. Black generally plays 14g6 to stop White's knight from going to f5. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–Zaitseva Variation) was advocated by Igor ZaitSEv, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today, followed by the Classical Defence. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped.
A50: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast. It originated in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. In the United States the name was changed in the early twentieth century to Cornish. A white variant, the White Cornish, was developed there at about the same time, and is much used in modern industrial chicken meat production in many parts of the world. The Indian Game was bred as a gamecock, but was not successful as a fighting bird.
A68: The Benoni Defense, or simply the Benoni, is a chess opening characterized by an early reply of ...c5 against White's opening move 1.d4. It is named after an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow" Aaron Reinganum, a prominent member of the Frankfurt Jewish community, published a book entitled Ben-Oni oder die Vertheidigungen gegen die Gambitzüge im Schache (1825) in which he analyzed several defenses to the King's Gambit. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4 in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. Benoni Variation: A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6 A79 1. d4 N f 6 2. c4 c4 3. d5 e 6 4. Nc3 formerd5 exd 5. cxd5. d6.e 4 g6 8.Bb5+Four Pawns Attack: A68 1.e. Benoni Defense1 (Benoni Defense): A65.
A57: Benko Gambit is a chess opening characterised by the move 3...b5 in the Benoni Defence. Black sacrifices a pawn for enduring queenside pressure. In many countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the opening is known as the Volga Gambit (Russian: Волжкий гамбит) The name is derived from an article about 3... b5!? by B. Argunow written in Kuibyshev (Samara since 1991), Russia. The Pal Benko Gambit is a chess opening named after the eponym Pal Benco. It is considered to offer Black good practical chances of playing for a win. The most popular line is 4...bxc4, the Sosonko Accepted, which often leads to sharp and sacrificial lines for both sides. Other lines include the Poisoned Knight Variation where after 5.Nc3 e6 6.e4 exd5 and 7.e5, Black sacrifices a knight for a large central pawn majority.
C65: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves: 1. e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5ECOC60–C99OriginGöttingen manuscript, 1490Named afterRuy López de Segura, Libro del Ajedrez, 1561ParentKing's Knight OpeningSynonym(s)Spanish Opening Spanish Game Spanish Torture [colloquial] Due to the difficulty for Black in achieving equality, a common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish torture" 3...a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Ruyopez. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws).[55] The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost. The main line continues 10d4 Nbd7 11Nbd2 12.a4, 12.d5 and 12.b4. White's most important continuations after 4...Bc5 are 5.0-0, 5.Bxc6, and 5.c3. An uncommon reply to 4.d3 is 4...Ne7, which tries to set up the Mortimer Trap.
E33: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. Black often follows up with ...b6 and ...Bb7. By pinning White's knight, Black prevents the threatened 4.e4 and seeks to inflict doubled pawns on White. The Rubinstein System (named after Akiba Rubinstein) is Black's most common method of combating the opening. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation, (7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 cxd4 9.exd4 b6) is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. Black may play 9...b6, with the intention of playing ...cxd4 at some point to isolate the d-pawn and blockade it, or exchange on c3 as well to play against the isolated c3–d4 pawn couple. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...Dxc4 Nc6 or 7...Nc6. After 7...Nc6, White has tried 11.Be2, 11.Bd3,11.Bb2, and 11.Qe2. Black will play a quick ...e5 to pressurize d4. If White has a bishop on d3, then Black also threatens ...e4 forking it and the knight on f3. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. 4...c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4... c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert Hü bner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5 or 4. e3 d5 5.Ne2 b6 6.a3 Ba5. The American Variation is another name for the line 5. Ne2 Ne4, as it was pioneered by GM Isaac Kashdan and then developed by GM Bisguier, Anthony Santasiere and currently GM Nick de Firmian. White has two ways to attack Black's setup: 8.cxd5 exd5 followed by 10.f4 and transferring the queen or f1-rook to h3 via f3. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common Black replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5 or 5... 0-0 6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6). In the former case, the bishop will eventually retreat to e7 and Black will set up a Hedgehog formation. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. Today as White, this is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov and former Women's Champion Nona Gaprindashvili. White develops the knight to a natural square and waits to see Black's reply. C91: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" The Morphy Defence is the most commonly played third move for Black. It forces White to retreat or exchange for Black's knight. 3...a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Ruyopez. Most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today, followed by the Classical Defence. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–Zaitseva Variation) was advocated by Igor Zait sev, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. The Classical Defence or Cordel Defence (ECO C64), 3...Bc5 is possibly the oldest defence to the Ruy Lopez.
C98: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e5, 2.Nf3 Nc6, 3.Bb5. It is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. The Morphy Defence, 3...a6, forces White to retreat or exchange for Black's knight. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. After 5...f3, Black usually plays e-c3 to defend the e-pawn, with 5...Qd6 preparing the sharp line 5...Bg6. In the Modern Steinitz Defence (also. called Neo-Steinitz Defence), 5 ...Bc5 is the most common move. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8. The Kholmov Variation, 9...Be6, was popular in the 1980s but is now played less often at the master level. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today, followed by the Classical Defence. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3. The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost.
E05: The Catalan Opening is a chess opening where White plays d4 and c4 and fianchettoes the white bishop on g2. A common opening sequence is 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.g3, although various other openings can transpose into the Catalan. The Catalan has had proponents at the highest level in chess, with Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. A61: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. In 1825 Aaron Reinganum, a prominent member of the Frankfurt Jewish community, published a book entitled Ben- oni oder die Vertheidigungen gegen die Gambitzüge im Schache. In the 1843 Staunton–Saint Amant match, Saint Amant met 1.d4 with 1...c5 in the second and fourth games. The Old Benoni Defense starts with 1. d4 c5. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4, in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. Black appears to retain the advantage against both setups. C53: The Italian Game is a family of chess openings beginning with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4ECOC50–C59Origin15th or 16th centuryParentKing's Knight Opening. Black's two main options are 3...Bc5, the Giuoco Piano, and 3...Nf6, the Two Knights Defense. It is part of the large family of Open Games or Double King's Pawn Games. 3...Nd4 (Blackburne Shilling Gambit) is a false gambit expectant upon White falling into the trap of capturing Black's undefended pawn (4.Nxe5?! Qg5). After 3...Qf6?! 4.Nc3 Nge7 5.Nb5 White has a clear advantage (Unzicker).3...h6. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time;[3] however, it has no immediate refutation and has been tried by Czech grandmaster Pavel Blatny.
A95: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack in the middlegame on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and challenger David Bronstein played it in their World Championship match. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839 against von der Lasa, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines, although Black must then be ready to play the French Defence if White continues 2.e4. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) has twenty codes for the Dutch Defence, A80 through A99. Qc2 7.Qc2 (Ilyin–Genevsky Variation) A99: 1:d4. f5 1.c3 e3 2.e3 Nf4 3. e3 4. e4 5. e5 6. e6 6. Bg3 Be7 7. b4 e5 8. b5 Be7 8. Ba3 (Botvinnik Variations)
A59: Benko Gambit is a chess opening characterised by the move 3...b5 in the Benoni Defence. Black sacrifices a pawn for enduring queenside pressure. In many countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the opening is known as the Volga Gambit (Russian: Волжкий гамбит) The name is derived from an article about 3... b5!? by B. Argunow written in Kuibyshev (Samara since 1991), Russia. The Pal Benko Gambit is a chess opening named after the eponym of a famous chess player. It is used by many of the world's strongest players, including former world champions Viswanathan Anand, Garry Kasparov, Veselin Topalov, and Mikhail Tal. It offers Black fast development, good control of the a1–h8 diagonal, and good pressure down the half-open a- and b- files. Black does not generally mind if queens are exchanged, as it removes the sting from a kingside attack by White.
A92: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack in the middlegame on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and his challenger, David Bronstein, played it in their 1951 World Championship match. The Staunton Gambit is an attacking line that offers White equality at best. White has various more aggressive alternatives to the standard moves, including 2.Nc3 Nf6 (or 2...d5) 3.Bg5, the Raphael Variation; e.g. 2...Nf6 is the most popular move. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines, although Black must then be ready to play the French Defence if White continues 2.e4. A66: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have successfully used it. Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5. White may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4, in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5.[5] Grandmaster Ben Finegold often plays this line; he notably beat Mamedyarov in this variation. Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. The Catalan has been a favorite of Anatoly Karpov and Efim Geller as well as of Romain Geller and Oleg Geller. A32: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1. c4. It is the fourth most popular and one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen, and Ding Liren have employed it during their world championship matches. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5. All irregular responses such as 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. After 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. C38: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4, regaining the Gambit pawn with central domination. It is infrequently seen at master level today, as Black has several methods to obtain equality, but is still popular at amateur level. It was one of the most popular openings until the late 19th century, when improvements in defensive technique led to its decline in popularity. The main reason is that it is hard to gain an advantage with strong opponents. The Kieseritzky Gambit, 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5, is considered by modern writers such as John Shaw and Joseph Gallagher to be the main line after 3...g5. Boris Spassky used it to beat Bobby Fischer in a famous game at Mar del Plata in 1960. The Long Whip Variation, 5...h5?! 6.Bc4 Rh7 (or 6...Nh6) is considered old-fashioned and risky, as Black loses a lot of time attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. The move has received renewed attention following its recommendation by John Shaw in his 2013 book on the King's Gambit. A well-known trap here is 4...g4 5.Ne5 Qh4+ 6.g3 fxg3 7.Qxg4 g2+? The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. The MacLeod Defense, 3...Nc6, is named after Nicholas MacLeod. The Bishop's Gambit allows 3...Bc4+ 4...Qh4+ but loses the right to lose the castle. Black's most popular option, it attracted some attention in 2020 when Ding Liren used it to beat Magnus Carlsen. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit, as he says that Black is better in all variations. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. It runs 1.e4 e5 2.f4 d5 3.exd5 e4, in which Black sacrifices a pawn in return for quick and easy development. The King's Gambit is one of the oldest countergambits in Chess. It is considered dubious because 3.exf5 with the threat of Qh5+ gives White a good game. The variation is sometimes named the Pantelidakis Countergambit because GM Larry Evans answered a question about it in Chess Life and Review. White may also offer the gambit in the Bishop's Opening, e.g. 1.e4 e5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.f4, though this is uncommon.

It can also transpose into lines of the Queen's Gambit or Queen's Indian Defence. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Ba5 9.Bg5 Bb7 10.Rc1 and 11.Qe2 are good moves for White. After 4.e3 0-0, White has a huge selection of moves to choose from, and Black must be familiar with all of them. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. If Black can prevent White from achieving this, then they will enjoy the better game. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above. In the Rubinstein, White often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. 4.e3 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo-Indian game, though it was superseded by the Rubinstein Variation. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation has become unplayable at the highest level. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. It is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov and former Women's Champion Nona Gaprindashvili. E94: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) It is a hypermodern opening, where Black deliberately allows White control of the centre with pawns, with the view to challenge it. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings classifies it under the codes E60 through E99. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and plays for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6). This can transpose to the Modern Benoni after 5...0-0 6.Bg5 c5 7.d5 e6. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. The Averbakh Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5. The Fianchetto Variation 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3. nf3 Bf3 4.g3 0-1 5.bg2 d6 6.0-0 is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. White has other setups, such as Nf3 and h3 and Nge2 (with or without Bd3), but these are currently not as popular at the grandmaster level. E60: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast. It originated in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. In the United States the name was changed in the early twentieth century to Cornish. A white variant, the White Cornish, was developed there at about the same time, and is much used in modern industrial chicken meat production in many parts of the world. The Indian Game was bred as a gamecock, but was not successful as a fighting bird.
A04: The Sokolsky Opening is an uncommon chess opening that begins with the move:1. b4. Out of the twenty possible first moves from White, the move 1.b4 ranks ninth in popularity. It is considered an irregular opening, so it is classified under the A00 code in the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings. The opening is largely based upon tactics on the queenside or the f6- and g7-squares. Black can respond in a variety of ways: For example, a common response is for Black to make a claim on the centre, which White's first move ignores. 1...c5 is usually used to avoid theory. After 1...a5 White will most likely play 2.b5 and take advantage of Black's queenside weakness. Black will generally place pressure on the c5-square and will develop an attack against White's weak queenside structure at the cost of an inferior central position. Black's 1... c5 is much sharper and more aggressive and is normally used toavoid theory. White plays 1...e5 and Black plays 1 ...c5.
C36: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4. It is infrequently seen at master level today, as Black has several methods to obtain equality, but is still popular at amateur level. It was one of the most popular openings until the late 19th century, when improvements in defensive technique led to its decline in popularity. It has been played by many of the strongest players in some of the greatest brilliancies. The Kieseritzky Gambit, 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5, is considered by modern writers such as John Shaw and Joseph Gallagher to be the main line after 3...g5. Boris Spassky used it to beat Bobby Fischer in a famous game at Mar del Plata in 1960. The Long Whip Variation, 5...h5?! 6.Bc4 Rh7 (or 6...Nh6) is considered old-fashioned and risky, as Black loses a lot of time attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. A well-known trap here is 4...g4 5.Ne5 Qh4+ 6.g3 fxg3 7.Qxg4 g2+? (7.Nxg 4 d5 is about equal) The Becker Defense has the idea of creating a pawn chain on h6, g5, f4 to defend the f4 pawn while avoiding the Kieseritzky Gambit. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. The MacLeod Defense, 3...Nc6, is named after Nicholas MacLeod. Black's most popular option, it attracted some attention in 2020 when Ding Liren used it to beat Magnus Carlsen in the online MagnusCarlsen Invitational tournament. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit, as he says that Black is better in all variations. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. It runs 1.e4 e5 2.f4 d5 3.exd5 e4, in which Black sacrifices a pawn in return for quick and easy development. The King's Gambit is one of the oldest countergambits in Chess. It is considered dubious because 3.exf5 with the threat of Qh5+ gives White a good game. The variation is sometimes named the Pantelidakis Countergambit because GM Larry Evans answered a question about it in Chess Life and Review. White may also offer the gambit in the Bishop's Opening, e.g. 1.e4 e5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.f4, though this is uncommon.
C09: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience, although some lines such as the Winawer Variation can lead to sharp complications. Black's natural French Defence move 6...c5 runs into 7.Bxe7 when Black must either move the king with 7...Kxe7 or allow 7...Qxe7 8.Nb5! The Advance Variation is one of the most difficult openings to play in chess. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The main line continues 5.Ngf3 Nc6 6.Bb5 Bd6 7.0-0 Nge7 8-dxc5 Bxc5 9.Nf3 Bb6. The Advance declined in popularity throughout most of the 20th century. It was revived in the 1980s by GM and prominent opening theoretician Evgeny Sveshnikov. In recent years, it has become nearly as popular as 3. nd2. GM Alexander Grischuk has championed it successfu. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance is considered one of the most difficult openings in the world to play. It is played with a pawn structure that is symmetrical and symmetrical with the pawns on the same side of the board. It can also be played with two pawns in the same position, as in 3.Nc3 or 3.c4.

A19: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen and Ding Liren have employed it during their world championship matches. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5. All irregular responses such as 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. After 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The many different transpositional possibilities available to White make the English a slippery opening for Black to defend against. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. The opening is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. The English Opening was first written by Edward Winter in the early 19th century. There are many variations of the opening, including the Fianchetto Line and the Symmetry Line. Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7) White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. Qg4, giving Black two choices: he may sacrifice his kingside pawns with 7... Qc7 8.Qxg7 Rg8 9. Qxh7 cxd4 or he can play 7...0-0 8.Bd3 Nbc6. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings includes an alphanumeric classification system for openings that is widely use. The system was developed by Russian chess theoretician Evgeny Sveshnikov. A28: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. C25: The Vienna Game is an opening in chess that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nc3ECOC25–C29. The original idea behind the Vienna Game was to play a delayed King's Gambit with f4 (the Vienna Gambit) In modern play White often plays more quietly (for example, by fianchettoing his king's bishop with g3 and Bg2). Black most often continues with 2...Nf6. The opening can also lead to the Frankenstein–Dracula Variation. The Mieses Variation is a quiet continuation in which White fianchettoes his king's bishop, a line played by Vasily Smyslov on a few occasions, most notably in a win over Lev Polugaevsky in the 1961 USSR Championship. The late American master Ariel Mengarini advocated the whimsical 3.a3. The best line may be 3...Bc5 (better than 5...e4 6...d4, when the normal 6...Reb4 is impossible) The Hamppe–Muzio Gambit is characterised by the continuation 3...exf4 4.Nf3 g5 5.Bc4 g4 6.0-0 gxf3 7.Qxf3 (see diagram) The Steinitz Gambit was a favorite of Wilhelm Steinitz, the first World Champion. Louis Paulsen played 1.e4 e5 2.Nc3 Nc3 four times with the white pieces in the Vienna 1873 chess tournament. After 3.f4, ...d6 leads to the King's Gambit Declined. Weak is 3.Qg4 Nf6! 4.Qxg7 Rg8 5.Qh6 Bxf2+ when Black had a large advantage in Tsikhelashvili–Karpov, USSR 1968. 6.Bg5 (6.Be2 d5 7.e5 Ne4 8.0-0 Nxc3 leads to equality[16]) h6 7.Bh4 0-0 8.Nb3 and now de Firmian in MCO-15 gives 8...Bb4.
E73: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) It is a hypermodern opening, where Black deliberately allows White control of the centre with pawns, with the view to subsequently challenge it. The opening is a favourite of former world champions Garry Kasparov and Bobby Fischer. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and is content to play for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6). This can transpose to the Modern Benoni after 5...0-0 6.Bg5 c5 7.d5 e6. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. The Four Pawns Attack continues with 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f4 0-0 6.Nf3. With their fifth move, White erects a massive centre at the price of falling behind in development. From this 6...c5 is the main line. If White makes neutral moves such as 7.Bd3, this has had success. On the other hand, 7.e 5 is the most aggressive plan. White has other setups, such as Nf3 and h3 and Nge2 (with or without Bd3), but these are currently not as popular at the grandmaster level. 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. C22: The Center Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.d4 exd4. The game usually continues 3.Qxd4 Nc6, developing with a gain of tempo for Black due to the attack on the white queen. The best move for the queen seems to be 4.Qe3, known as Paulsen's Attack. White intends to castle queenside in this line. Black can safely transpose to the Scotch Game, Petrov's Defense or the Philidor Defense.
A10: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen, and Ding Liren have employed it during world championship matches. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5 whereupon even though ...e4 has been delayed, once it is played the defence is classified as a Reversing Sicilian. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack. After 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. The opening is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C82: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5. It is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. White's objective in playing the Ruyopez is to spoil Black's pawn structure. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. The Exchange Variation, 4.Bxc6, (ECO C68–C69) White damages Black’s pawn structure, gaining a ready-made long-term plan of playing d4 ...exd4 Qxd4. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3...a6 with the active move ...Bc5. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–ZaitseV Variation) was advocated by Igor ZaitSev, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. The main line runs 10.d4 Bxb3 11.axb3 (11.Qxb3 is another option) exd4 12.cxd4 d5 13.e5 Ne4 14.Nc3 f5 15.exf6 Bxf6 16.Nxe4 dxe4 17.Rxe4 Qd5 18.Rg4. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws)
E20: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response to 4...e5. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxf4 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8.bxf4 (Smyslov) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6 (Bronstein) After 7...Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 Qc7 is the Khasin Variation, named after International Master Abram Khasin. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight, thus avoiding the doubled pawns. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Ne2 (Modern Variation) 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position, though eventually superseded by the Rubinstein-Indian Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. After 5.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5 is nowadays the main line of the Classical Variation. After 7...Bb7, White's most straightforward move is 8.f3 preparing e4, but Black can counter with 8...h6 9.Bh4 d5? White has sometimes tried 8.e3 instead. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5 and possibly transferring the c6-knight over to the kingsside after White's d5. A44: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow" It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have successfully used it. Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. White may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4, in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority. Benoni: A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6 A79 1.e3 Nf4 2. c4 3.c3 4.c5 4. c5 5c3 5. cxd5 6. e4 7.e2 8.f3 9.Nf3 Bg 7 8. be2 9. be3 10.a4 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9 A10 A11 A12 A13 A14 A15
C76: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO), all codes from C60 to C99 are assigned to the Ruyopez. The Morphy Defence: 3...a6 is the most commonly played third move for Black. 3... a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Riy Lopez. The most commonly playing line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. After 4...dxc6, Black almost always responds 4...Dxc6. The Kholmov Variation, 9...Be6, was popular in the 1980s but is now played less often at the master level. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. The Berlin Defence, 3...Nf6, has long had a reputation for solidity and drawishness and is commonly referred to as "the Berlin Wall" The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. Less-common third moves for Black:3...Bb4 (Alapin Defence)3...Qf6 (Gunderam Variation) 3...F6 (Nuremberg Defence) and 3...Qe7 (Cordel Defence)
C49: The Four Knights Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Nc3 Nf6ECOC47–C49Named afterKnights on c3, c6, f3, f6ParentThree Knights Game. The opening is fairly popular with beginners who strictly adhere to the opening principle: "Develop knights before bishops." It was one of the workhorses in the family of the Open Game, at even the highest levels, until World War I. 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Bc5 4.Nc3 Nf6 4...Bc5 5.Nxe4 d5 7.Neg5+ Kg8 5.Bxf7+?, though superficially attractive, relinquishes the bishop pair and central control to Black. E27: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. Black often follows up with ...b6 and ...Bb7. The opening remains the most commonly used amongst the open games in master play. It has been adopted by almost all players during their careers, many have played it with both colours. The Kholmov Variation, 9...Be6, was popular in the 1980s but is now played less often at the master level. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today, followed by the Classical Defence. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped.

E29: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Ba5 9.Bg5 Bb7 10.Rc1 and 11.Qe2 are good moves for White. After 4.e3 0-0, White has a huge selection of moves to choose from. Black will play a quick ...e5 to pressurize d4. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. In general, the main line of the Rubinstein has held up very well for Black, so since the 1980s White has begun to look elsewhere for chances of obtaining an advantage. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above. 4...c5 is one of the most popular positions in chess. The game can transpose to the main line mentioned above after moves such as 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0. The Hübner Variation was popularized by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky in 1972 with great effect. The Rubinstein Variation is similar in spirit to the Reshevsky Variation: White prevents Black from doubling their pawns. The main variations emerging from these are:5.2 Ba6 (Fischer Variation) 5.2 c5 (Romanakhis Variation), 5.5. Ne4 (The Fischer Variation or Fchetto) or 6.3 Bd3 (Keres) The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6), while White will try to pursue a strategy of gaining queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century. It was the discovery of 12.Qd2! which revived this line for White. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. Today as White, this is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov. E75: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) It is a hypermodern opening, where Black deliberately allows White control of the centre with pawns, with the view to subsequently challenge it. The earliest known use of the term "Indian Defence" was in 1884. 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. In the Exchange Variation (7.dxe5 dxe5 8.Qxd8 Rxd8), White exchanges queens and is content to play for a small, safe advantage in relatively quiet positions. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5 (prepared by ...c6 and/or ...a6). This can transpose to the Modern Benoni after 5...0-0 6.Bg5 c5 7.d5 e6. Black can strike for the centre as previously mentioned or delay with 6...Nc6. The Four Pawns Attack continues with 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f4 0-0 6.Nf3. With their fifth move, White erects a massive centre at the price of falling behind in development. From this 6...c5 is the main line. Black intends to claim the centre with ...e7–e5. 9...Re8 can be justified with solid play. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. A11: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen, and Ding Liren have employed it during world championship matches. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5. All irregular responses such as 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows. Bobby Fischer used it in Pawn Sacrifice in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. The opening is written in descriptive notation, rather than algebraic, as the former was contemporary in the late 19th century. It is also known as the "King's English" and the "Symmetrical" Opening. C23: The Bishop's Opening is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. Bc4. White attacks Black's f7-square and prevents Black from advancing the d-pawn to d5. By ignoring the beginner's maxim "develop knights before bishops", White leaves their f- pawn unblocked, preserving the possibility of f2–f4. It has an affinity with the King's Gambit and the Vienna Game. Transpositions into the Giuoco Piano and the Two Knights Defense and other openings are also possible. The Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit is named after English players and chess writers Samuel Boden and Lionel Kieseritzer. Boden published the first analysis of it in 1851. Black has a solid position with no clear weaknesses, but White has attacking chances and piece activity as compensation for the pawn. The Urusov Gambit can be reached via the Petrov Defence after 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.d4 exd4 4.Bc4. In practice, Black's lack of development and inability to castle kingside can prove very problematic. Black's most energetic response to the Philidor Variation is the Lewis Countergambit, 3.c3 d5. Black can transpose into the Evans Gambit, for instance by 3.b4 Bxb4 4. c3 Ba5 5.Nf3 Nc6. Other moves are considered inferior since they hamper White's development or leave the queen exposed, leading to loss of tempo. Black can strike for the centre as previously mentioned or delay with 6...Nc6, 7...a6 and 8...Rb8. The Averbakh Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5. The Fianchetto Variation 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3. nf3 Bf3 4.g3 d6 6.0-0, is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. The Four Pawns Attack is a method of development on completely different lines than other King's Indian variations. White has other setups, such as Nf3 and h3 and Nge2 (with or without Bd3), but these are currently not as popular at the grandmaster level. 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. One of the most famous King's Indian games was a brilliancy by the late Ukrainian-American grandmaster Eduard Gufeld, who called it his "Mona Lisa" E86 King's Indian, Sämisch, Orthodox, 7.Nge2 c6E87 King'sIndian, Sámisch,. Orthodox,7.d5 c6, 7...Nbd7, 8.Re1, Main line. E90 King's. Indian, 5.Nf3, 6.Be2, 7....Nf4, 8...Nf5, 9.Ne1. E93 King's Russian, Petrosian system, Main lines, 7 ...Nbd5, 8 ...Nf6, 9...Nb5. E94 King's Canadian, Orthodox Variation.
A27: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1. c4. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from the leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton. Bobby Fischer created a stir when he switched to it from his customary 1.e4 late in his career. Mikhail Botvinnik, Tigran Petrosian, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Magnus Carlsen, and Ding Liren have employed it during their world championship matches. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7, before controlling the fifth rank with moves such as a6 and d6. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. Black can delay playing ...e5, for example 1.c4 Nf6 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 e5 whereupon even though ...e4 has been delayed, once it is played the defence is classified as a Reversing Sicilian. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack. Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. If White plays an early d4, the game will usually transpose into either the Queen's Gambit or an Indian Defence. The many different transpositional possibilities available to White make the English a slippery opening for Black to defend against. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. The opening is one of the oldest in the world, having been written by Edward Winter in the late 19th century. There are many variations on the opening, including the Fianchetto Line and the Keres Variation. Chess is a type of chess. Chess is one of the most popular chess games in the world. There are more than 1,000 chess tournaments worldwide. Chess can be taught by playing the game alone or with help from a teacher. Chess tournaments include the Chess Olympiad, the Chess World Cup, and the Chess Grand Prix. For more information on chess, see chess.org and chess.com. For a list of chess tournaments, see Chess.org. For an overview of the chess world, see the Chess.com website.
C15: The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience, although some lines such as the Winawer Variation can lead to sharp complications. Black's position is often somewhat cramped in the early game; in particular, the pawn on e6 can impede the development of the bishop on c8. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. An obsession with obtaining one one pawn sometimes results in embarrassment for White. White will often play c2–c2 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated pawn on c4 to give White's pieces greater freedom. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s by GM and prominent opening theoretician Evgeny Sveshnikov. In recent years, GM Alexander Grischuk has championed it successfully at t. 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. There are also a few rare continuations after 1.e4 e6 2. d4 d5, including 3.Bd3 and 3.Be3.  4. e4 e5 5. e5 e6 6. e6 e7 7. e7 e7 8. e8 e8.
E43: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 7...Nc6 8.a2 Ba5 (Larsen) or 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6 is the Bronstein Variation. The Rubinstein Variation has a huge selection of moves to choose from, and Black must be familiar with all of them. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. If Black can prevent White from achieving this, then they will enjoy the better game. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6), while White will try to pursue a strategy of gaining queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are all common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. 4...d5 transposes to the Ragozin Defence of the Queen's Gambit Declined and 4...b6. The Nimzo/Queen's Indian hybrid line is the most common move that stays within Nimzo-Indian territory. Black has dissolved White's centre, but the bishop on g2 exerts pressure on the black queenside, which White may augment with 9b3. C41: The Philidor Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 d6. The opening is named after the famous 18th-century player François-André Danican Philidsor. It is considered a good opening for amateur players who seek a defensive strategy that is simpler and easier to understand than the complex positions that result from an opening such as the French Defence. The most common Black response is 3...exd4 which relieves the central tension, although it gives up the centre. The Hanham Variation aims to maintain Black's pawn on e5, analogously to closed lines of the Ruy Lopez. Black can develop a strong initiative after, for example, 10...b5 11.Nxb5 Qa5+) 6...0-0 7.a4 (to prevent ...b5) c6 (see diagram) Black sometimes tries 3...Nd7 intending 4.Nc3 Ngf6, but then 4...Bc4! is awkward for Black to meet. Chess is a game of chess. Chess is an art form. Chess tournaments include the Chess Olympiad, the Chess World Cup and the FIDE Grand Prix. Chess can be played in many ways, including the rook pawn position and the pawnless endgame. There are many types of chess games, including many different types of pawns and bishops. Chess has its roots in ancient Greek and Roman chess. It is one of the oldest games in the world, dating back to the 6th century.
A73: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5, and later with 1. d4 Nf6 2.c 4 c5 and other openings in which Black counters d2–d4 with an early ....c7–c5, without first having played ...d7–d5. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4 in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority, whose advance will be supported by a fianchettoed bishop on g7. E17: The Queen's Indian Defense is a chess opening defined by the moves: d4 Nf62, c4 e63, Nf3 b6. The opening is a solid defense to the Queen's Pawn Game. Black attempts to control the center with pieces in hypermodern style, instead of occupying it with pawns in classical style. It is regarded as the sister opening of the Nimzo-Indian, since both openings aim to impede White's efforts to gain full control of the center by playing e2–e4. The classical main line of the Queen's Indian, the most frequently played line from the 1950s until 4...Ba6 became popular in the 1980s, usually continues: 5. Bg2 Be7 6.0-0 0-0 7. Nc3 Ne4 8. Qc2 Nxc3 9. Qxc3. White has tried various deviations from the main line in an attempt to unbalance the play. These include:8. Bd2, which defends the knight on c3 and threatens a d4–d5 push. 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 2,3 b6 3.Nf3 Bb7 4.Bg5E14 – 1.d3 bb7 5. Bg2 Be7 6.0-0 0-0 7.Nc3 Ne4 8.Qc2[edit] 2. d4 Nc3 e6 3,2 b6 4. Nf3 b4 5. Nc5 e6 6. Bb4 Bb5 7. Bf5 Bb6 8. Qc4 Ne4 9. Qd4 E6 10. Qe5 Ne4 11. Qf4 E7 12. Qh4 Ne5 13. Qb4 Ne6.
A87: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack in the middlegame on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and challenger David Bronstein played it in their 1951 World Championship match. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839 against von der Lasa, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) has twenty codes for the Dutch Defence, A80 through A99. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines, although Black must then be ready to play the French Defence. A94: 1.d4 f5 2.c4 Nf6 3.g3 e6 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 d6 7.Nc3 Qe8 (Ilyin–Genevsky Variation) A96: 1-1 1-2 1-3 1-4 1-5 1-6 1-7 1-8 1-9 1-12 1-14 1-15 1-16.
E28: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response to 4...e5. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Bxc3 dxc3 9.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6. After 4.e3 0-0 White has a huge selection of moves to choose from, and Black must be familiar with all of them. Black will play a quick ...e5 to pressurize d4. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight. 4...c5 is the most popular move in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4... c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert Hü bner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky in 1972. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5 or 4.E3 c5 5.Ne2 b6 6.a3 Ba5!? The American Variation is another name for the line 5. Ne2 Ne4, as it was pioneered by GM Isaac Kashdan and then developed by GM Bisguier, Anthony Santasiere and currently GM Nick de Firmian. White has two ways to attack Black's setup. The first is to play 8.cxd5 exd5 9.Ne5 followed by 10.f4 and transferring the queen or f1-rook to h3 via f3. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are the most common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (6.a3 Bxc3+ 6.Qxc3 b6 7.Bg5) The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. Today as White, this is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov.
