E10: Blumenfeld Countergambit is a chess opening characterised by the moves 3...e6 4.Nf3 b5 in the Benoni Defense. Black sacrifices a wing pawn to establish an imposing centre with pawns on c5, d5 and e6. White, on the other hand, will typically look to counter in the centre by playing e4 at some point. The opening is named after the Russian master Benjamin Blumenfeld, and was later played by World Champion Alexander Alekhine.
A74: Benoni (or "Ben-Oni") is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin. In 1825 Aaron Reinganum, a prominent member of the Frankfurt Jewish community, published a book entitled Ben-oni oder die Vertheidigungen gegen die Gambitzüge im Schache. In the 1843 Staunton–Saint Amant match, Saint Amant met 1.d4 with 1...c5 in the second and fourth games. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. Black may play Nc3, e4, h3, Bd3, Nf3, and g4 in order to gain space on the kingside and prevent ...f5. The Benko Gambit begins 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 b5. Black's intention is to play ...exd5 and create a queenside pawn majority. C46: The Four Knights Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Nc3 Nf6ECOC47–C49Named afterKnights on c3, c6, f3, f6ParentThree Knights Game. It was one of the workhorses in the family of the Open Game, at even the highest levels, until World War I. In the 1990s, this opening saw a renaissance, and is now seen in the praxis of players from beginner to grandmaster. 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Bc5 4.Nc3 Nf6 5.Nxe4 d5 7.Neg5+ Kg8 8.d3 h6 9.Nh3 Bg4 4...d5 5.0-0 6.Bd3 7.Bxe4 Bd6 8.Nxd4 exd4 10.Qxd4 0-0 11.Be3 (Tartakower–Atkins, London 1922[5]) and 11.Qxe4 Qe7 (11.0? Bxh2+ wins) Black has a decisive advantage after 5...Bb4. The Halloween Gambit is one of the most popular chess moves of all time. It is a variation of the famous Three Knights Defense. It has been used in a number of chess tournaments, including the 2010 World Chess Championship in Moscow, Russia. The trick is to get the opponent to play a certain way in order to win. For more information on the game, see: http://www.chess.com/halloween-gambit/ and http:// www.cheek.org/Halloween- Gambit.
C79: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Black usually plays 5...f3 to defend the e-pawn, with 5...Bg6 preparing the sharp line 5...Qd6. White steers clear of the Marshall Attack and any of the anti-Marshall lines. The Marshall Attack is a very sharp system in which a great amount of theoretical knowledge is vital. Black generally goes all-in with a massive kingside attack, which has been analysed to great depth. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–Zaitseve Variation) was advocated by Igor ZaitSEv, who was one of Karpov's trainers for many years. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8 and 11.Nbd2 Bf8. The Kholmov Variation, 9...Be6, was popular in the 1980s but is now played less often at the master level. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3. The Classical Defence or Cordel Defence (ECO C64), 3...Bc5, is possibly the oldest defence to the Ruy Lopez.
C84: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. The theory of the Ruyopez is the most extensively developed of all Open Games. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. The Exchange Variation, 4.Bxc6, (ECO C68–C69) White damages Black's pawn structure, gaining a ready-made long-term plan of playing d4 ...exd4 Qxd4, followed by exchanging all the pieces. The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. White plays 9.d3 intending to later advance to d4 under favourable circumstances. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8. Black generally plays 14g6 to stop White's knight going to f5. The Berlin and Schliemann Defences are the most popular today, followed by the Classical Defence. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost.
A42: Modern Defense is a hypermodern chess opening in which Black allows White to occupy the center with pawns on d4 and e4. Black then proceeds to attack and undermine this "ideal" center without attempting to occupy it. The opening has been most notably used by British grandmasters Nigel Davies and Colin McNab. The Modern Defense is closely related to the Pirc Defence, the primary difference being that in the Modern, Black delays developing the knight to f6. The delay of ...Nf6 attacking White's pawn on e4 gives White the option of blunting the g7-bishop with c2–c3. After 2.Nf3, Black can play 2...c5, transposing to the Sicilian Defense, or 2...Bg7. Black can transpose to a closed Sicilian with 2...C5 or play 2 ...Bg6. The Averbakh system is reached after 2...Nc3 and 2...b7. In 1974, Canadian GM Duncan Suttles, one of the Modern's leading exponents, defeats Czech-American GM Lubomir Kavalek at the Nice Olympiad.
C70: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. The Exchange Variation, 4.Bxc6, (ECO C68–C69) White damages Black's pawn structure, gaining a ready-made long-term plan of playing d4 ...exd4 Qxd4. The Dilworth Variation (or Attack), 11...Nxf2 12.Rxf2 f6 13.exf6 Bxf2+ 14.Kxf2 Qxf6 has scored well for Black. The main line leads to unbalanced endgames which are difficult to play for both sides. The Pilnik Variation, named for Hermann Pilnik, is also known as the Teichmann Variation. White plays 9.d3 intending to later advance to d4 under favourable circumstances. With 9...Bb7 Black prepares to put more pressure on e4 after 10.d4 Re8. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. The Classical Defence or Cordel Defence (ECO C64), 3...Bc5 is possibly the oldest defence to the Ruy Lopez. The Steinitz Defence (3...d6) is solid but passive and cramped. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws)
E26: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It is a highly respected defence to 1.d4 and has been played by every world champion since Capablanca. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Ba5 9.Bg5 Bb7 10.Rc1 and 11.Qe2 are good moves for White. After 4.e3 0-0, White has a huge selection of moves to choose from. Black must be familiar with all of them. White will try to advance their centre pawns to free their bishops: c4, d5, and f3 followed by e4 are all possible. If Black can prevent White from achieving this, then they will enjoy the better game. White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight, thus avoiding the doubled pawns. 4...c5 is one of the most popular moves in chess. The game can still transpose to the main line mentioned above after moves such as 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0. The Hübner Variation was popularized by Bobby Fischer in his world championship match with Boris Spassky in 1972 with great effect. The Rubinstein Variation is similar in spirit to the Reshevsky Variation: White prevents Black from doubling their pawns. The main variations emerging from these are:5.2 Ba6 (Fischer Variation) 5.2 c5 (Romanakhis Variation), 5.5 Ne4 (The Fischer Variation or Fchetto) or 5.3 Bd3 (Keres) The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5 or 4.E3 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. Black often sets up a Hedgehog formation (pawns on a6, b6, d6 and e6) while White tries to gain queenside space with b4 and c5. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4…d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with the. knight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. It is a favourite weapon of GM Alexei Barsov and former Women's Champion Nona Gaprindashvili. Bd3 d4 7. c5 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)[edit]List of chess openings.
A89: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Like its 1.e4 counterpart, the Sicilian Defence, the Dutch is an aggressive and unbalancing opening. It has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. Its most notable use may have been in 1951, when both world champion Mikhail Botvinnik and his challenger, David Bronstein, played it in their 1951 World Championship match. White has various more aggressive alternatives to the standard moves, including 2.Nc3 Nf6 (or 2...d5) 3.Bg5, the Raphael Variation; e.g. 2...Nf6 is the most popular move. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) has twenty codes for the Dutch Defence, A80 through A99. A94: 1.d4 f5 2.c4 Nf6 3.g3 e6 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 d5 7.b3 c6 8.Ba3 (Stonewall) A95:1. d4 f4 2. c4 N f5 3. g3 e5 4. Bg1 Be7 4. Nf3 e-6 5. Nc3 Qe8 7.Nc3 Bc2 8.Qc2 (Ilyin–Genevsky Variation) A99: 1-1 D4 F5 2-1 Nf5 3-3 Nf4 4-4 Df4 5-5 Df5 6-6 Df6 7-7 Df7 7-8 Df8 8-9 Df9
E19: The Queen's Indian Defense is a chess opening defined by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nf3 b6. The opening is a solid defense to the Queen's Pawn Game. It is regarded as the sister opening of the Nimzo-Indian Defense. Both openings aim to impede White's efforts to gain full control of the center by playing e2–e4. Black attempts to control the center with pieces in hypermodern style, instead of occupying it with pawns. The classical main line of the Queen's Indian, the most frequently played line from the 1950s until 4...Ba6 became popular in the 1980s, usually continues. White has tried various deviations from the main line in an attempt to unbalance the play. These include:8. Bd2, which defends the knight on c3 and threatens a d4–d5 push. 8. Nc3, which postpones castling in favor of preparing action in the center. 9... c5, 9... f5 or 9... Be4. E13 – 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 b6 4.Nc3 Bb7 5.Bg2 Be7 6.0-0 0-0 7. Nc3 Ne4 8.Qc2[edit] 7.N c3 Ne 4 8. Qc2 7.0/0 0/0 8. Nf3 Ne3 8.Nb3 Ne2 8.2/0 9. Nb4 Ne3 9.
E21: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. It was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch who introduced it to master-level chess in the early 20th century. It can also transpose into lines of the Queen's Gambit or Queen's Indian Defence. Black's delay in committing to a pawn structure makes it a very flexible defence to 1.d4. 4...0-0 is the most flexible and frequently played response to 4...e5. The Karpov Variation is one of Black's most reliable defences to the Rubinstein System. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Ba5 or 7...Nc6 8.A3 Bxc3 dxc3 9.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) or 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6. After 4.e3 0-0 White has a huge selection of moves to choose from, and Black must be familiar with all of them. After 7...Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 Qc7 is the Khasin Variation, named after International Master Abram Khasin. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 at some point to be able to recapture on c3 with the knight, thus avoiding the doubled pawns. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s and utilised by Bobby Fischer. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo-Indian, though eventually superseded by the Rubinstein-Indian. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5 (the Pirc Variation) Black can also try 6...Ne4 (see 4.e3 b6) 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. White usually plays on the queenside in this variation, while Black will try to play on the kingside with ...f5. C77: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Bb5. The opening is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" The Morphy Defence is the most commonly played third move for Black. 3...a6 is played in over 65 percent of all games beginning with the Ruyopez. Black almost always responds 4...dxc6. White steers clear of the Marshall Attack and any of the anti-Marshall lines. Frank James Marshall used it as a variation against José Raúl Capablanca in 1918. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911. Boris Spassky has a career-plus score with the Breyer. The Chigorin Variation has declined in popularity because Black must spend some time bringing his offside knight on a5 back into the game. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns. Henry Bird played it as Black at least 25 times, scoring +9−13=3 (nine wins, thirteen losses, three draws) The world champion Magnus Carlsen played it in the 2014 Chess Olympiad against Ivan Šarić and lost. The Classical Defence or Cordel Defence (ECO C64), 3...Bc5 is possibly the oldest defence to the Ruy Lopez.
A45: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. The breed was developed by Sir Walter Gilbert, of Bodmin in Cornwall, in about 1820. It was intended to be a gamecock, but had no aptitude for cockfighting. In the United States the name was changed in the early twentieth century to Cornish. A white variant, the White Cornish, was developed there at about the same time and is much used in modern industrial chicken meat production.
C83: The Ruy Lopez is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e5, 2.Nf3 Nc6, 3.Bb5. It is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. The Morphy Defence, 3...a6, forces White to retreat or exchange for Black's knight. The most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. White steers clear of the Marshall Attack and any of the anti-Marshall lines. Black defends the e-pawn with 6...d6 instead of driving away the white bishop. The Marshall Attack is the most common move after 11...c6. The Breyer Variation was recommended by Gyula Breyer as early as 1911. Boris Spassky has a career-plus score with the Breyer. Black generally plays 14g6 to stop White's knight going to f5 from going to e4. The main line continues 10d4 Nbd7 11b7 11Nbd2 12.a4, 12.d5, 12b4, or the main line 12.Bb7 or ...Bd7. The Zaitsev Variation (also called the Flohr–ZaitseV Variation) was advocated by Igor ZaitSEv. The Schliemann Defence is a sharp line in which Black plays for a kingside attack, frequently sacrificing one or two pawns.
C48: The Four Knights Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. e4 e52. Nf3 Nc63. Nc3 Nf6. The opening is fairly popular with beginners who strictly adhere to the opening principle: "Develop knights before bishops" It was one of the workhorses in the family of the Open Game, at even the highest levels, until World War I. In the 1990s, this opening saw a renaissance, and is now seen in the praxis of players from beginner to grandmaster. 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Bc5 4.Nc3 Nf6 is a favourite among younger players due to its simple and easy development. Black can preserve the symmetry by 4...Bc5, leading to the quiet Giuoco Pianissimo. After 4...Nxe4, Black can perform the center fork trick by pseudo-sacrificing a knight with 4... Nxe4!. Then 5.Bxf7+?, though superficially attractive, relinquishes bishop pair and central control to Black. The Halloween Gambit is a chess move. It is one of the most popular chess moves of all time. The game is played in a number of different ways. It can be played in any number of ways, depending on the strategy used. For more information on the game, see: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/30/chess/halloween-gambit.html#storylink=cpy. Follow us on Twitter @CnnHalloween and @CannHalloween.
D98: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4, giving White an imposing central pawn duo. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school, which was coming to the fore in the 1920s, held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of  development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variant with White. The Hungarian Variation, 7...a6, has been championed by Peter Leko. After 7...Nc6, White will most commonly play 8.Be2, followed by 8...e5! The Grünfeld Gambit is not often met in top-flight play today, its usage having declined significantly since its heyday in the 1930s. In statistical databases this variation shows only a slightly higher percentage of White wins and draws, as opposed to the Exchange Variation. Systems in which White delays the development Nc3 are known as the Neo-Grünfield Defence (ECO code D70–D79). Typical move orders are 1.d4 Nf6 2.g3 g6 3.c4 d5 or, more commonly, 1. d4 nf6. 3.f3Chessgames: Neo-Grünfeld 3.g3InternationalFASTNationalGermanyIsraelUnited StatesRetr.  3. f3 is a variant of 3. g3. 3.f2 is a modified version of the 3.3 version. It is a variation of the 4.2 version of this game. It has been released in Germany, Israel and the U.S. as well as in other countries around the world. For more information, visit chessgames.com.
B05: The opening is named after Alexander Alekhine, who introduced it in the 1921 Budapest tournament in games against Endre Steiner[2] and Fritz Sämisch. Black tempts White's pawns forward to form a broad pawn centre, with plans to undermine and attack the white structure later in the spirit of hypermodern defence. Bobby Fischer used it in two games against Boris Spassky in the World Chess Championship 1972, and Viktor Korchnoi also included the defence in his repertoire. The Four Pawns Attack is White's most ambitious line against the Alekhine's. Black allows White to make several tempo-gaining attacks on the knight. The game can become very sharp since White must either secure an advantage in space or make use of it before Black succeeds in making a successful strike at it. While the main target of Black is d4, the pawn on c4 also can be pressurized considerably via ...Na5. Black must also play vigorously because passive play will be crushed by the white centre. The Voronezh Variation is the most common response to Black's 5...exd6 line. Black usually aims to attack and undermine the white pawn on d4, and possibly c4 as well. After 10.d5 Ne5 Black's knight lacks a target, and will soon be chased out with f2–f4. Other solid moves such as 9...e6, ...Bd7,...Bf5, and ...a5 are possible. Black will often voluntarily surrender by parries with 5Be2 or 5Be3. 4...dxe5 (the Larsen Variation) eliminates the advanced pawn, but brings forward the white knight after 5.Nxe5. Challenging this knight immediately with 5...Nd7 can lead to the sharp sacrificial line 5. Nxe5 Nd7 6.Nxf7!? Kxf7 7.Qh5+ Ke6. White's most popular move is 6.Be2 (6.Bd3!?) when Black continues with either the immediate 6...nd7 or 6...Bf5. In the Two Knights Variation, White immediately accepts doubled pawns after 3...Nxc3 for some compensation. After 4.dxc3 this compensation is rapid piece development. Black must play 4...Nd5, whereupon White will usually challenge the knight with moves like Bc4 and Nc3. The statistics presented by Cox show this variation scoring poorly for White, with all of Black's main defences scoring at least 50%. The first recorded use of the Brooklyn Variation was in 1905 in Vienna where Adolf Aronzowitsch with white checkmated on the 34th move. 2.Nc3 is by far White's most common alternative to 2.e5. The independent Alekhine line is 2...d5, known as the Scandinavian Variation. White gets a large advantage with 3.d4 f6, or 3...e6 4.Nh3 h6 5.Qg4 d5 6.f3 h5 7.Qf4 g5 8.Nxg5 Nxg 5 9.Qxg4 Be7 10.Qe6+! 7.Be2 or 7.Ne2, 7...Bd7 is unpleasant. After 3...d4, Black can choose among 3...Nfd7 (transposing to the Steinitz variation of the French Defence after 4. d4 e6, but 4.e6!? is a sharp alternative), 3...Ne4!?, and even 3....Ng8. 2.Bc4, the Krejczik Variation, is rarely seen, since it allows Black to gain the bishop pair and seize space in the centre. After 2...Nxe4 3.Bxf7+ (the Krejcik Gambit) Kxf7 4.Qh5+ Kg8 or 4...g6 5.Qd5+ e6 6.Qxe4 Bg7 7.Qf4 Ke8! "Black has nothing to worry about," says Alburt and Schiller.
D53: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line is the most common variation of the opening. Other variations have their own names and are usually treated separately. The opening became a topical topic after its adoption by Mikhail Botvinnik in his 1963 match with Tigran Petrosian. Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening, which leads to one or the other side accepting isolated or hanging pawns in exchange for dynamic compensation. White has several ways of dealing with Black's setup. White can transpose to the Semi-Slav. or the Ragozin Variation. The Cambridge Springs Defense was introduced more than a century ago, and is still popular among amateurs. Black can fall into several traps, for example the Elephant Trap. Black has a back-up plan if White tries to play the Orthodox Defense. White has two main moves: 8.Bd3 and 8.Rc1 c6. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense. The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4 in the Three Knightsvariation. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. This line has been played by top grandmasters such as Wesley So, Anish Giri, and Magnus Carlsen aiming for a draw. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5.[19] Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match. The Three Knights Variation is also a popular line.
D54: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line is the most common, but there are other variations of the opening. Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening, which often leads to one or the other side accepting isolated or hanging pawns in exchange for dynamic compensation. Of the 34 games played in the 1927 World Championship between Alexander Alekhine and José Raúl Capablanca, all except the first and third began with this opening. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4. The Janowski Variation threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. White has several ways of dealing with Black's setup. Black can fall into several traps, for example the Elephant Trap. White will try to use his advantage in space to attack, whereas Black will try. to keep White at bay while striking back at the centre. Black has a back-up plan if White fails to play the Orthodox Defense. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense. The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4 in the Three Knightsvariation. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. This line has been played by top grandmasters such as Wesley So, Anish Giri, and Magnus Carlsen aiming for a draw. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5.[19] Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match. The Three Knights Variation is also a popular line.
B02: The opening is named after Alexander Alekhine, who introduced it in the 1921 Budapest tournament. Black tempts White's pawns forward to form a broad pawn centre, with plans to undermine and attack the white structure later in the spirit of hypermodern defence. Bobby Fischer used it in two games against Boris Spassky in the World Chess Championship 1972, and Viktor Korchnoi also included the defence in his repertoire. The opening's current highest-rated proponent is GM Vassily Ivanchuk, although Lev Alburt played it almost exclusively during his career. The Four Pawns Attack is White's most ambitious line against the Alekhine's. Black allows White to make several tempo-gaining attacks on the knight. The game can become very sharp since White must either secure an advantage in space or make use of it before Black succeeds in making a successful strike at it. Black must also play vigorously because passive play will be crushed by the white centre. An alternative is the sharp Planinc Variation (also known as the Cambridge Gambit), 5...g5!? Black hopes for 6.fxg5? dxe5. The Voronezh Variation is named after the Russian city where the line was invented. It is defined by the opening sequence 1.e4 Nf6 2.e5 Nd5 3.d4 d6 4.c4 Nb6 5.exd6 cxd6 6.Nc3 g6 7.Be3 Bg7 8.Rc1 0-0 9.Bg5 9.Nd5 Ne5 10.dxe5 dxe5 11.Qxd8 Rxd8 12.c5 N6d7 (This retreat is forced since 12...Nc6?? loses the knight due to the 13.Rd1 pin) Black must play carefully to unentangle the white pawn on c5. 4...dxe5 (the Larsen Variation) eliminates the advanced pawn, but brings forward the white knight after 5.Nxe5. Challenging this knight immediately with 5...Nd7 can lead to the sharp sacrificial line 5. Nxe5 Nd7 6.Nxf7!? Kxf7 7.Qh5+ Ke6. White usually replies with 5.Bc4, the Keres Variation. 4...g6, preparing to fianchetto a bishop to oppose White's central pawn mass, is also often seen. This variation was played in the thirteenth game of the Match of the Century. In the Two Knights Variation, White immediately accepts doubled pawns after 3...Nxc3 for some compensation. After 4.dxc3 this compensation is rapid piece development. Black must play 4...Nd5, whereupon White will usually challenge the knight with moves like Bc4 and Nc3. The statistics presented by Cox show this variation scoring poorly for White, with all of Black's main defences scoring at least 50%. The first use of the Brooklyn Variation was in 1905 in Vienna where Adolf Aronzowitsch with white check on the 34th move was recorded. 2.Nc3 is by far White's most common alternative to 2.e5. The independent Alekhine line is 2...d5, known as the Scandinavian Variation. White gets a large advantage with 3.d4 f6 (or 3...e6 4.Nh3 h6 5.Qg4 d5 6.f3 h5 7.Qf4 g5 8.Nxg5 Nxg 5 9.Qxg4 Be7 10.Qe6+! 7.Be2 or 7.Ne2, 7...Bd7 is unpleasant") 4.g3 has been played by the Danish correspondence player Ove Ekebjaerg, when Harald Keilhack recommends 4...Nxc3 Qd5! 2.Bc4, the Krejczik Variation, is rarely seen, since it allows Black to gain the bishop pair and seize space in the centre. 2.Bd3 aims to transpose into a Kopec System. 2...e5 (transposing to the Bishop's Opening), 2...d5 and 2... e6 are also playable alternatives. The John Tracy Gambit is a poor choice, leading to the loss of the king pawn for doubtful compensation. The Latvian Gambit can in effect wind up playing it after 1.e4 Nf6 2.f3 e5 3.f4!?.
B34: The Sicilian Defence is the most popular and best-scoring response to White's first move 1.e4. It is named after Giulio Cesare Polerio, who analysed it in his 1594 book King's Pawn Game. Black's c5-pawn is traded for White's d4-p pawn in the early stages of the game. The pawn trade also opens the c-file for Black, who can place a rook or queen on that file. Black can then choose between four major variations: the Najdorf, Dragon, Classical and Scheveningen. The Sveshnikov Variation was pioneered by Evgeny SvesHnikov and Gennadi Timoshchenko in the 1970s. The old main line 7.Nb3 is now less popular than the modern 7.nf3. The Kasparov Gambit 8...d5 was played twice in the World Chess Championship 1985, but virtually disappeared from master praxis after the game Karpov–Van der Wiel, Brussels (SWIFT) 1986. Black's move 2...e6 gives priority to developing the dark-squared bishop. White can play 2.Nf3 without intending to follow up with 3.d4. Black sometimes plays 3...e5 to avoid both moves; then 4.Bc4 is considered White's best move. The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular chess openings, named after the Sicilian city of Sveshnikov. It can be played with the Tal Gambit Declined or the Najdorf Variation, both of which are named after places in the city of Najdorf.
